For the text of the new Code-wide definitions, see General Provisions Article, §§ 1-101 (In general), 1-102 (“Adult”), 1-103 (“City”), 1-104 (“City Code” or “Code”), 1-105 (“Includes” or “Including”), 1-106 (“Minor”), 1-107 (“Person”), 1-108 (“State”), and 1-109 (“Street”).

section.heading: In general.
section.text: In this article, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

section.heading: Commissioner.
section.text: "Commissioner" means the Commissioner of Health or the Commissioner's designee.

section.heading: Department.
section.text: "Department" means the Baltimore City Department of Health.

section.heading: Physician.
section.text: "Physician" means an individual authorized by law to practice medicine in the State of Maryland.

section.heading: Police officer.
section.text: "Police officer" includes, to the extent of that individual's authority, any individual authorized to act as a Special Enforcement Officer under City Code Article 19, § 71-1 {"Special Enforcement Officers — Appointment; duties"}.

annotation.text: Ord. 22-125 amended this subtitle to delete several rules of interpretation that were superseded by uniform Code-wide rules codified in the newly enacted General Provisions Article. The sections remaining in this subtitle have been renumbered by authority of Section 2 of Ord. 22-125.

For the text of all of the Code-wide rules of interpretation, see General Provisions Article, §§ 1-201 (In general), 1-203 (Gender), 1-204 (Mandatory, prohibitory, and permissive terms), 1-205 (Singular and plural), 1-208 (Captions or headers), 1-209 (Editor’s or Revisor’s Notes), 1-211 (Effect of repeal or amendment of statute), 1-212 (References to other laws), 1-214 (Severability), and 1-301 et seq. (Time Computations).

section.heading: In general.
section.text: In interpreting and applying this article, the following rules of interpretation apply:

para.text: those contained in Subtitles 2 and 3 of the City Code's General Provisions Article; and
any additional rules contained in this subtitle.

para.heading: Article sets minimum requirements.
para.text: In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this article must be taken to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of the public health, safety, and general welfare.

para.heading: Most restrictive provision governs.
para.text: If any condition imposed by a provision of this article is either more or less restrictive than a comparable condition imposed by any other provision of this article or by any other law, rule, or regulation of any kind, the condition that is the more restrictive governs.

section.heading: Mail.
section.text: Whenever this article requires the use of "registered mail" or "certified mail", either method may be used.

section.heading: Short title.
section.text: This article may be cited as the "Health Code of Baltimore City".

section.heading: Department established.
section.text: There is a Department of Health, as established in Article VII, § 54 of the City Charter.

section.heading: Commissioner.
section.text: The head of the Department is the Commissioner of Health, who is appointed as provided in Article VII, § 55 of the City Charter.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Commissioner may appoint deputies, assistants, professional employees, and other officers and employees as provided in the Ordinance of Estimates.

para.heading: Identification.
para.text: While on duty, all officers and employees of the Department must have and, on request, display official identification denoting their employment.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: There is a Suicide Prevention Coordinator within the Health Department.

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: The Suicide Prevention Coordinator shall:
collaborate with system partners to support behavioral health system management; and
work to prevent suicides and mental health crises.

para.heading: Duties.
para.text: The Suicide Prevention Coordinator is authorized to:
reach out to community organizations, groups and agencies to inform them about available resources regarding suicide prevention;
coordinate and provide suicide prevention trainings and trainings regarding the relationship between trauma and suicide as needed;
carry out new public awareness prevention strategies;
distribute resource materials as appropriate;
generally collaborate with:
the State Behavioral Health Administration's Office of Suicide Prevention;
the Baltimore Police Department;
the Fire Department;
local emergency departments;
Baltimore Crisis Response;
the Baltimore City Public School System;
academic partners;
people with mental health conditions; and
other local agencies and services;
collaborate with the Health Department's Child Fatality Review team and the Health Department's Maternal Mortality Review team to develop and implement prevention plans;

collaborate with emergency departments, pediatricians, primary care physicians, the Baltimore City Public School System, and colleges and universities to encourage screening for suicidality and to establish continuity of care for patients at risk of suicide;
develop and coordinate a data collection and analysis plan to determine trends regarding suicides and suicide attempts;
develop a plan of action to reduce suicides in Baltimore City;
provide consultations to mental health, school, juvenile, and social services professionals;
represent the Health Department in interagency meetings and committees;
support system accountability to ensure that services are responsive to the behavioral health needs of Baltimore City residents;
work with diverse populations in Baltimore City to actively decrease stigma associated with mental health; and
fulfill other related duties as assigned by the Health Commissioner.

para.heading: Potential contractual position.
para.text: The Health Commissioner may elect to contract with the local behavioral health authority to fill the Suicide Prevention Coordinator position.

section.heading: Commissioner's Charter powers.
section.text: Under Article VII, § 56 of the City Charter, the Commissioner has the general care of and responsibility for:

para.text: enforcing all laws for the preservation of the health of the inhabitants of the City;
the study and prevention of disease, epidemics, and nuisances affecting public health; and
establishing and implementing policies for:
treating and preventing physical and mental illnesses; and
educating the public about environmental, physical, and mental health.

section.heading: General duties.
section.text: In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Commissioner has the following duties:

para.text: to observe and inspect areas in and near the City that might be health hazards;
to enforce all laws relating to health and the correction of health hazards;
in the absence of a law needed to correct a health hazard, to report and recommend to the Mayor any extraordinary action needed;
to investigate and report all cases of communicable diseases and take immediate action to stop their spread;
to remove and abate nuisances; and
to report to and advise the Mayor and other City authorities on all matters relating to the preservation of the health of the people.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Commissioner may adopt and enforce rules and regulations to carry out this article.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Commissioner may, at all reasonable times, enter any structure or premises within the City:
whenever the Commissioner has reason to believe that a health hazard, nuisance, or violation of this article exists in or is emanating from that structure or premises;
to inspect any property, facilities, equipment, operations, animals, records, or other things required or authorized by this article to be inspected; or
otherwise as necessary or appropriate to enforce this article.

para.heading: "Dwelling" defined.
para.text: In this subsection, "dwelling" has the meaning stated in § 5-301(b) of this article.

para.heading: Governing procedures.
para.text: The entry and inspection of a dwelling must be made in accordance with § 104.6 {"Right of entry"} of the Baltimore City Building Code.

para.heading: Search warrant.
para.text: A search warrant must be obtained in accordance with § 104.6 {"Right of entry"} of the Baltimore City Building Code, except as otherwise specified in that section.

annotations.annotation: City Code, 1976/83, art. 11, §26(e), inter alia, art. 11, §105, art. 19, §9

section.heading: Physicians to report and assist.
section.text: On notice from the Commissioner, any practicing physician in the City must provide information, advice, and assistance to the Commissioner in all matters that relate to the preservation of the health of the people and the prevention of communicable diseases.

section.heading: Police to execute orders.
section.text: Baltimore City Police Officers are directed to execute all orders of the Commissioner that relate to the preservation of the health in the City.

section.heading: Obstructing, etc., Departmental personnel.
section.text: No person may knowingly obstruct, resist, or interfere with the Commissioner or any officer or employee of the Department while carrying out their powers and duties.

section.heading: Impersonating Departmental personnel.
section.text: No person may, without authority to do so:

para.text: use any identification issued to employees of the Department; or
otherwise represent him- or herself as an employee of the Department.

section.heading: Failure to comply with Commissioner's order or notice.
section.text: No person may refuse, neglect, or otherwise fail to comply with any order or notice issued under this article by or under the authority of the Commissioner.

section.heading: Violation a misdemeanor.
section.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to the penalties provided in this Part III.

section.heading: Basic penalty: $500.
section.text: Except as otherwise specified in this Part III, the penalty for a violation of this subtitle is a fine of not more than $500 for each offense.

annotations.annotation: City Code, 1976/83, art. 11, §3(3rd par.(last cl.)), §5(last cl.)

section.heading: Failure to obey notice or order: $200 plus $50/day.
section.text: Unless a higher penalty is specified in this article for the same offense, the penalty for a violation of § 2-207 {"Failure to comply with order or notice"} of this subtitle is a fine of not more than $200 for each offense, plus $50 for each day that the offense continues.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as otherwise specified in this article, this subtitle applies whenever:
a person is aggrieved by a notice, order, decision, or other action of the Department; or
the Department proposes to deny, revoke, suspend, or refuse to renew a license or permit.

para.heading: Exclusion for animal control and protection.
para.text: This subtitle does not apply to matters that:
relate to the Health Department's Office of Animal Control, or
otherwise arise under Title 10 {"Animal Control and Protection"} of this article.

Before the Commissioner takes any final action to deny, revoke, suspend, or refuse to renew a license or permit, the Commissioner must notify the person against whom the action is contemplated of the proposed action.
The notice must:
be in writing; and
state that a hearing will be provided if, within 10 days of the notice (or any longer period specified in the notice), the person files with the Commissioner a written request for a hearing.
In all other situations, any person aggrieved by a notice, order, decision, or other action of the Department may request a hearing on the matter.
The request must:
be in writing;
state the grounds on which the person is contesting the notice, decision, order, or other action; and
unless a different time is specified in this article, be filed with the Commissioner within 10 days of the notice, decision, order, or other action.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Hearings may be conducted by:
the Commissioner; or
a hearing officer designated by the Commissioner.

para.heading: Scope of delegation.
para.text: The Commissioner may delegate to a hearing officer the authority to issue:
proposed or final findings of fact;
proposed or final conclusions of law;
proposed or final findings of fact and conclusions of law;
proposed or final orders; or
the final administrative decision of the Department.
The Commissioner must provide all parties reasonable written notice of the hearing.
The notice must state:
the date, time, place, and nature of the hearing;
the right of a party to be represented, at the party's own expense, by an attorney or, if permitted by law, other representative;
the right of a party to call witnesses and submit documents or other evidence under § 2-305 of this subtitle; and
that failure to appear for the scheduled hearing may result in an adverse action against the party.

para.heading: Hearings to be open and informal.
para.text: Except as otherwise provided by law or by rule or regulation of the Department, all hearings must be:
open to the public; and
conducted in an orderly but informal manner.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as otherwise provided by this section or by rule or regulation of the Department, formal rules of evidence and trial procedures do not apply.

para.heading: Right to submit.
para.text: On a genuine issue of fact, a party is entitled to:
call witnesses;
offer evidence, including rebuttal evidence;
cross-examine any witness that another party or the Department calls; and
present summation and argument.

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: The Commissioner or hearing officer:
may admit probative evidence that reasonable and prudent individuals commonly accept in the conduct of their affairs and give probative effect to that evidence;
may not exclude evidence solely on the basis that it is hearsay;
must give effect to a privilege recognized by law;
may receive documentary evidence in the form of copies or excerpts or through incorporation by reference;
may take official notice of a fact that is judicially noticeable or that is general, technical, or scientific and within the specialized knowledge of the Department; and
may exclude evidence that is:
incompetent;
irrelevant;
immaterial; or
unduly repetitious.

para.heading: Form and contents.
para.text: A final decision must:
be in writing; and
contain separate statements of:
the findings of fact;
the conclusions of law; and
the decision or order.

para.heading: Distribution.
para.text: A copy of the final decision must be mailed or delivered to each party or that party's attorney of record.

para.heading: Judicial review.
para.text: A party aggrieved by a final decision under this subtitle may seek judicial review of that decision by petition to the Circuit Court for Baltimore City in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

para.heading: Appellate review.
para.text: A party to the judicial review may appeal the court's final judgment to the Court of Special Appeals in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

section.heading: "Nursing home" defined.
section.text: In this subtitle, "nursing home" means:

para.text: a comprehensive care facility, as defined in COMAR 10.07.02.01B(6);
an assisted living program, as defined in COMAR 10.07.14.02B(10); and
an extended care facility, as defined in COMAR 10.07.02.01B(12).

section.heading: Cooling requirements.
section.text: From June 1 through September 30 of each year, every nursing home must maintain and operate, throughout all rooms and areas that are occupied or used by residents, a cooling system that maintains a temperature of less than 82° F.

para.heading: Commissioner to develop.
para.text: The Commissioner must develop standards and requirements for the following items used in nursing homes:
patient lifting and mobility equipment;
bathroom and shower equipment; and
linens and toiletries.

para.heading: Nursing homes to comply.
para.text: Every nursing home must comply with the standards and requirements adopted under this section.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle is subject to a civil fine of not more than $1,000 for each offense.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day that a violation continues is a separate offense.

section.heading: Commissioner may establish.
section.text: The Commissioner of Health may establish health clinics and centers in the City.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Commissioner must adopt guidelines and procedures for the administration and operation of these clinics and centers.

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: Among other matters, the guidelines and procedures must govern:
the eligibility of individuals for services; and
the fees to be charged for those services.

section.heading: Fees.
section.text: Fees for services at City clinics and centers:

para.text: may not exceed the actual cost of the services; and
must be approved by the Board of Estimates.

section.heading: Establishment.
section.text: To prevent morbidity or mortality constituting a threat to public health, the Commissioner of Health, with the approval of the Mayor may:

para.text: rent or erect suitable structures for temporary hospitals or places to receive the sick or infected; and
require sick or infected individuals to be moved to these temporary hospitals or places.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: In the rules and regulations adopted under § 2-106 {"Rules and regulations"} of this article, the Commissioner may, with the approval of the Mayor, adopt rules and regulations to govern:

para.text: all temporary hospitals or places established under this section; and
all individuals residing in or in any way concerned with them.

annotations.annotation: Text conformed to include express cross-reference to § 2-106. Cf. Editor’s Note to that section.

section.heading: Individuals too sick to move.
section.text: If an individual cannot be moved without danger to his or her health, the house or place where he or she remains is considered to be a temporary hospital for purposes of this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates a rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $500 for each offense.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day that a violation continues is a separate offense.

section.heading: "Limited-service pregnancy center" defined.
section.text: In this subtitle, "limited-service pregnancy center" means any person:

para.text: whose primary purpose is to provide pregnancy-related services; and
who:
for a fee or as a free service, provides information about pregnancy-related services; but
does not provide or refer for:
abortions; or
nondirective and comprehensive birth-control services.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A limited-service pregnancy center must provide its clients and potential clients with a disclaimer substantially to the effect that the center does not provide or make referral for abortion or birth-control services.

para.heading: How given.
para.text: The disclaimer required by this section must be given through 1 or more signs that are:
written in English and Spanish;
easily readable; and
conspicuously posted in the center's waiting room or other area where individuals await service.

section.heading: Violation notice.
section.text: If the Health Commissioner learns that a pregnancy center is in violation of this subtitle, the Commissioner shall issue a written notice ordering the center to correct the violation within 10 days of the notice or within any longer period that the Commissioner specifies in the notice.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The failure to comply with an order issued under § 3-503 {"Violation notice"} of this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Abnormal EPSDT screening.
para.text: "Abnormal EPSDT screening" means a medical screening done as part of an EPSDT regimen that produces:
inconclusive results;
ambiguous results; or
results that require further testing.

para.heading: Baltimore City Public School System.
para.text: "Baltimore City Public School System" or "BCPSS" means the public school district of the City of Baltimore.

para.heading: Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnosis, and Treatment.
para.text: "Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnosis, and Treatment" or "EPSDT" means the provision of preventive health care under 42 CFR Subpart B {"Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnosis, and Treatment (EPSDT) of Individuals Under Age 21"}, including medical and dental services to assess growth and development and to detect and treat health problems in Medicaid beneficiaries under 21 years old.

para.heading: Family Planning.
para.text: "Family planing" means providing individuals with the information and means to prevent an unwanted pregnancy and to maintain reproductive health.

para.heading: Follow-up care.
para.text: "Follow-up care" means:
any treatment or practice recommended as medically necessary to address abnormal or positive results of an EPSDT screening by a licensed healthcare professional; and
the process of attempting to ascertain if the recommended services have been obtained.

para.heading: Maryland Healthy Kids Preventive Health Schedule.
para.text: "Maryland Healthy Kids Preventive Health Schedule" means the schedule set by the State Department of Health's Healthy Kids Program as a minimum EPSDT practice for all Maryland Medicaid recipients under 21 years of age, consisting of:
standard health screenings;
physical exams;
laboratory tests;
immunizations; and
health education.

para.heading: Medically necessary.
para.text: "Medically necessary" means that a health service is:
directly related to diagnostic, preventive, curative, palliative, rehabilitative, or ameliorative treatment of an illness, injury, disability, or health condition;
consistent with currently accepted standards of good medical practice;
the most cost efficient service that can be provided without sacrificing effectiveness or access to care; and
not primarily for the convenience of the consumer, family, or provider.

para.heading: Positive EPSDT screening.
para.text: "Positive EPSDT screening" means a medical screening conducted by a licensed health professional as part of an EPSDT regimen that produces positive results indicating the presence of the tested-for condition.

para.heading: Preventive Health Services.
para.text: "Preventive Health Services" means proactive care to detect potential health problems and protect and maintain a patient's current health, including:
screenings for health conditions;
counseling for chronic conditions;
regular health checkups; and
immunizations.

para.heading: Primary health services.
para.text: "Primary health services" means a basic level of health care, including diagnostic, treatment, consultative, referral, and preventive health services, generally rendered by 1 or more:
general practitioners;
family practitioners;
internists;
gynecologists;
pediatricians;
physician assistants; and
nurse practitioners.

para.heading: School-based health center.
para.text: "School-based health center" means a facility providing medical care that:
is located on the grounds of a BCPSS facility;
provides on site primary and preventive health care, referrals, and follow-up services;
may provide on site dental care or behavioral health care, referrals, and follow-up services; and
has been approved by the Maryland Department of Health.

para.heading: School health services professional.
para.text: "School health services professional" or "school health professional" means a physician, certified nurse practitioner, or registered nurse with experience, special training, or both in working with children and families in community or school health programs and practices in accordance with the current State medical and nursing standards of care.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The following health services may be provided at any school-based health center:
comprehensive preventive and primary health services, including administration of vaccines according to the Maryland Healthy Kids Preventative Health Schedule;
access to family planning, dental, and mental health services; and
access to vision care at the written request of a child's guardian.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: For any positive or abnormal EPSDT screening of a student, the school health professional that performed the screening shall communicate the need for follow-up care, as appropriate and in accordance with all laws related to minor consent, to either or both of:
the student; or
the student's parent or guardian.

para.heading: Additional screening.
para.text: If a school health services professional determines that an additional screening or health check-up is necessary for a student, the professional shall make a recommendation for an additional screening or health check-up to the student or the student's parent or guardian, as appropriate.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act B Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Commissioner of the Baltimore City Health Department may adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle.

annotations.annotation: Ordinance 25-016 (effective August 25, 2025) numbered sections in this subtitle with the structure "[subtitle_number]-[section_number]" (e.g. "§ 6-101"). This structure does not follow the numbering conventions for sections in the Health Code. The proper structure is "[title number]-[subtitle number][section number]" (e.g. "§ 3-601"). The section numbers have been updated to follow the correct numbering convention.

para.heading: Reporting does not breach confidentiality.
para.text: The making of a report as required or permitted by this title is not a breach of a patient's confidentiality.

para.heading: Confidentiality of reports.
para.text: Except as otherwise required by law, all reports made under this title are confidential and not open to public inspection.

para.heading: Form.
para.text: All reports must be made in writing, in the form that the Commissioner requires.

para.heading: Contents.
para.text: In addition to any other information specified in this title or required by the Commissioner, all reports must contain the following patient information, to the extent known:
name;
place of dwelling;
date of birth or, if not known, approximate age;
sex;
race/ethnicity; and
occupation.

section.heading: Inspection of records.
section.text: The Commissioner may inspect the records of any person or facility subject to this title to determine compliance with this title.

para.heading: Duty to report.
para.text: Every physician must report to the Commissioner of Health every confirmed or suspected diagnosis of any disease or condition that, the Commissioner specifies by rule or regulation adopted under § 2-106 {"Rules and regulations"} of this article for purposes of this section .

para.heading: When to report.
para.text: Unless a different time is set by the Commissioner or by State law, the report must be made within 48 hours of the diagnosis.

para.heading: Contents of report.
para.text: In addition to the information required by § 4-102 {"Form and contents of reports"} of this title, the report must contain the following information:
the identity of the disease or condition; and
the date of its onset.

annotations.annotation: Text of subsection (a) conformed to include express cross-reference to § 2-106. Cf. Editor’s Note to that section.

para.heading: Reporting officer.
para.text: The chief administrative officer of each hospital, related institution, clinic, pharmacy, or other health care facility must appoint an individual from the facility's full-time staff to serve as the facility's reporting officer.

para.heading: Duty to report.
para.text: The reporting officer must report to the Commissioner every confirmed or suspected diagnosis of any disease or condition that the Commissioner specifies by rule or regulation adopted under § 2-106 {"Rules and regulations"} of this article for purposes of this section.

para.heading: When to report.
para.text: Except for specified diseases or conditions that the Commissioner or State law requires to be reported on a more timely basis, the report must be made within 48 hours for all patients who have been:
newly admitted to the facility;
admitted to an isolation ward;
treated on an emergency or out-patient basis; or
discharged without having been previously reported.

para.heading: Contents of report.
para.text: In addition to the information required by § 4-102 {"Form and contents of reports"} of this title, the report must contain the following information:
the identity of the disease or condition; and
the date of its onset.

para.heading: Nature of report.
para.text: The reporting of a disease or condition under this section does not absolve the attending physician of the duty to report the same disease or condition under § 4-201 {"Physicians"} of this subtitle.

annotations.annotation: Text of subsection (b) conformed to include express cross-reference to § 2-106. Cf. Editor’s Note to that section.

para.heading: Duty to report.
para.text: The individual in charge of any public or private medical laboratory must report to the Commissioner the result of any test of a specimen from a human body that is microscopic cultural, histological, pathological, immunological, serological, or other confirmed or suspected evidence of any disease or condition that the Commissioner specifies by rule or regulation adopted under § 2-106 {"Rules and regulations"} of this article for purposes of this section.
Unless a different time is set by the Commissioner or by State law, the report must be made within 48 hours of obtaining the test results.

When more than 1 specimen is taken from the same patient during a single disease episode, the individual in charge of the laboratory need not report every test result that shows evidence of the same disease if:
at least 1 positive test report is reported; and
the Commissioner approves in writing the reporting of less than all test results.

para.heading: Contents of report.
para.text: In addition to the information required by § 4-102 {"Form and contents of reports"} of this title, the report must contain the following information:
the date and type of test performed;
the results of the test;
the name and address of the physician for whom the examination was performed; and
if applicable, an enumeration of colonies of acid-fast bacilli, according to Diagnostic Standards of the American Thoracic Society.

para.heading: Test result not final diagnosis.
para.text: The result of a laboratory test:
is not to be considered a final diagnosis; and
does not absolve the attending physician of the duty to report her or his diagnosis of the case under § 4-201 {"Physicians"} of this subtitle.

annotations.annotation: Text of subsection (a) conformed to include express cross-reference to § 2-106. Cf. Editor’s Note to that section.

para.heading: When referral required.
para.text: The Commissioner may require that cultures containing acid-fast bacilli be referred to the Maryland State Laboratory unless they have been identified in accordance with standards set by the Commissioner.

para.heading: Effect of referral.
para.text: The referral of cultures does not:
satisfy the reporting requirements of § 4-203 {"Laboratories — in general"} of this subtitle; or
excuse delay in transmitting a presumptive culture result to the attending physician.

para.heading: "Lodging facility" defined.
para.text: In this section, "lodging facility" means any:
hotel or motel;
rooming house;
apartment house;
dwelling house; or
public or private institution in which individuals abide temporarily or permanently.

para.heading: Duty to report.
para.text: The individual in charge of a lodging facility must report to the Commissioner anyone in the lodging facility who is suffering from any disease or condition that the Commissioner specifies by rule or regulation adopted under § 2-106 {"Rules and regulations"} of this article for purposes of this section.

para.heading: When to report.
para.text: Unless a different time is set by the Commissioner or by State law, the report must be made within 24 hours of the individual's being told or otherwise becoming aware of the disease or condition.

annotations.annotation: Text of subsection (b) conformed to include express cross-reference to § 2-106. Cf. Editor’s Note to that section.

para.heading: Scope of section.
para.text: This section does not apply to a vessel that is in medical isolation.

para.heading: Duty to report.
para.text: The master, chief officer, or consignee of a vessel must report to the Commissioner anyone on board who is suspected of suffering from a communicable disease.

para.heading: When to report.
para.text: The report must be made immediately on the vessel's coming within ¼ mile of any dock, wharf, or building in the City.

para.heading: Contents of report.
para.text: In addition to the information required by § 4-102 {"Form and contents of reports"} of this title, the report must contain the following information:
the name and location of the vessel;
the name of the suspected communicable disease; and
the name and condition of all individuals on board suffering from the disease.

para.heading: Duty to report.
para.text: If a medical laboratory performs mycobacterial drug susceptibility tests of cultures that are identified as M. tuberculosis and that have not been referred to the Maryland Laboratories Administration for this determination, the individual in charge of the laboratory must report the test results to the Commissioner.

para.heading: When to report.
para.text: Unless a different time is set by the Commissioner or by State law, the report must be made within 48 hours of obtaining the test results.

para.heading: Duty to report.
para.text: The individual in charge of any public or private pharmacy, other than a facility operated by the Department, must report to the Commissioner of Health whenever it dispenses any anti- tuberculosis medication that the Commissioner specifies by rule or regulation adopted under § 2-106 {"Rules and regulations"} of this article for purposes of this section.

para.heading: When to report.
para.text: Unless a different time is set by the Commissioner or by State law, the report must be made within 48 hours of having dispensed the medication.

para.heading: Contents of report.
para.text: In addition to the information required by § 4-102 {"Form and contents of reports"} of this title, the report must contain the following information:
the type, and strength of medication issued;
the daily dosage;
the dosing schedule;
the total amount prescribed;
the name and address of the physician who issued the prescription; and
the date the medication was dispensed.

para.heading: Report not final diagnosis.
para.text: The prescription of medication:
is not to be considered a final diagnosis; and
does not absolve the attending physician of the duty to report her or his diagnosis of the case under § 4-201 {"Physicians"} of this subtitle.

annotations.annotation: Text of subsection (a) conformed to include express cross-reference to § 2-106. Cf. Editor’s Note to that section.

para.heading: Duty to conduct.
para.text: A physician who treats a patient with tuberculosis must:
thoroughly investigate all individuals who might have been exposed to the patient at home, work, or otherwise; or
request the Commissioner to undertake this investigation.

para.heading: Duty to report.
para.text: If the physician undertakes the investigation required by this section, the physician must report the results to the Commissioner.

para.heading: Contents of report.
para.text: In addition to any other information that the Commissioner requires, the report must contain:
evidence that an investigation has been thoroughly conducted;
the identity of the source case; and
the following information about each individual tested:
the date and type of test performed;
the results of the test; and
the personal information listed in § 4-102 {"Form and contents of reports"} of this title.

para.heading: Duty to notify.
para.text: If a patient with a confirmed or suspected diagnosis of tuberculosis leaves a ward, emergency room, or outpatient department of a hospital or other institution without the consent or against the advice of a physician or other individual in charge, the physician or other individual in charge must notify the Commissioner of the patient's departure.

para.heading: When to notify.
para.text: Unless a different time is set by the Commissioner or by State law, the notice must be given within 24 hours of the patient's departure.

para.heading: Action by Commissioner.
para.text: The Commissioner may take whatever action is needed to protect the public from that patient.

para.heading: Duty to notify.
para.text: If any patient being treated for tuberculosis discontinues treatment before the period that the Commissioner sets for that treatment, the attending physician must notify the Commissioner of the discontinuance.

para.heading: When to notify.
para.text: Unless a different time is set by the Commissioner or by State law, the notice must be given within 24 hours of the discontinuance.

para.heading: Action by Commissioner.
para.text: The Commissioner may take whatever action is needed to protect the public from that patient.

para.heading: Duty to report.
para.text: Every physician or medical examiner must report to the Commissioner if he or she believes that an individual he or she attended or examined has died of tuberculosis.

para.heading: When to report.
para.text: Unless a different time is set by the Commissioner or by State law, the report must be made within 48 hours of the death or the discovery of the disease, whichever is later.

para.heading: Contents of report.
para.text: In addition to the information required by § 4-102 {"Form and contents of reports"} of this title, the report must contain the place of death.

section.heading: "Communicable disease" defined.
section.text: In this subtitle, "communicable disease" means any contagious, infectious, or communicable disease or condition that the Commissioner specifies by rule or regulation adopted under § 2-106 {"Rules and regulations"} of this article for purposes of this subtitle.

annotations.annotation: Text conformed to include express cross-reference to § 2-106. Cf. Editor’s Note to that section.

section.heading: Investigations generally.
section.text: The Commissioner may investigate any report of a case or suspected case of a communicable disease or communicable disease carrier, to determine the source of infection and the need for restricting movement or isolating affected individuals.

para.text: Except as specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection, this section applies to any individual:
who has or whom the Commissioner of Health suspects on reasonable grounds of having a communicable disease;
who is or whom the Commissioner suspects on reasonable grounds of being a communicable disease carrier; or
who is or whom the Commissioner suspects on reasonable grounds of having been in contact with any individual described in item (i) or (ii) of this subsection.
This section may not be applied to interfere with any individual who is a bona fide practicing Christian Scientist and who receives treatment from registered Christian Science practitioners.

para.heading: Examination required.
para.text: On request of the Commissioner, any individual described in subsection (a) of this section must, for the purpose of determining if she or he has a communicable disease or is a carrier:
undergo a medical examination; and
submit specimens of body fluids, secretion, excretion, or discharge for laboratory examination.

para.heading: By whom made.
para.text: The medical examination may be made by:
the Commissioner or a physician selected by the Commissioner; or
at the option of the individual to be examined, any physician qualified to make this sort of examination.

para.heading: Report of physician.
para.text: The examining physician must promptly report the results of the examination to the Commissioner.

section.heading: Action to prevent spread; public notice of disease.
section.text: Whenever a communicable disease is found to exist, the Commissioner may:

para.text: take all possible action to prevent the disease from spreading; and
give public notice of the disease and of affected places, by all means that the Commissioner believes would be effective, including the posting of affected places.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Whenever an infectious agent is discovered in any dwelling or other building that is overcrowded, in a filthy and neglected state, or located in an unhealthy or crowded part of the City, the Commissioner, with the approval of the Mayor, may require the inhabitants of the building to move elsewhere while the City cleans and disinfects the building.

para.heading: City to bear expenses.
para.text: All expenses incurred under this section for moving, temporary housing, cleaning, and disinfecting are to be borne by the City.

section.heading: Medical isolation — in general.
section.text: In the rules and regulations adopted under § 2-106 {"Rules and regulations"} of this article, the Commissioner may require the medical isolation of individuals having a communicable or potentially communicable disease or condition dangerous to the public health.

annotations.annotation: Text conformed to include express cross-reference to § 2-106. Cf. Editor’s Note to that section.

section.heading: Medical isolation — court papers to be sealed.
section.text: In any court proceeding brought to enforce a medical isolation, all papers filed with the court:

para.text: must be sealed; and
may be inspected only by order of the court, on notice to the individual named in those papers and for good cause shown.

section.heading: Prohibited conduct.
section.text: No person may:

para.text: refuse, neglect, or otherwise fail to undergo an examination as required by § 4-403{"Examinations of individuals"} of this subtitle;
remove or deface any notice posted under § 4-404 {"Action to prevent spread; public notice of disease"} of this subtitle;
refuse, neglect, or otherwise fail to comply fully with an order for medical isolation issued under authority of § 4-406 {"Medical isolation"} of this subtitle;
needlessly expose others to the risk of a communicable disease, whether by exposure of him- or herself, another person, a dead body, or any infected material; or
otherwise, by reason of non-cooperation or carelessness, endanger the public health.

section.heading: In general.
section.text: Immunizations are a proven preventive measure in reducing the morbidity and mortality associated with childhood communicable diseases. Accordingly, to safeguard the public health and welfare, the City needs to attain and sustain an immunization coverage rate of at least 90% for age-appropriate vaccinations among infants and preschool children residing in the City.

section.heading: Parental responsibility.
section.text: Except as specified in § 4-506 {"Exceptions"} of this subtitle, every parent and guardian must provide for the timely and appropriate immunization of their minor children against all immunization-preventable childhood diseases, as specified by rule or regulation that the Commissioner adopts under § 2-106 {"Rules and regulations"} of this article.

annotations.annotation: Text conformed to include express cross-reference to § 2-106. Cf. Editor’s Note to that section.

section.heading: Scope of enforcement.
section.text: In enforcing this Part II, each child who is not properly immunized as required is considered a separate offense.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: In adopting rules and regulations under this Part II, the Commissioner must consider the recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices.

section.heading: Exceptions.
section.text: This Part II does not apply:

para.text: to any child whose parent or guardian, in accordance with the rules and regulations of the State Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene, objects to immunization on the ground that it conflicts with the parent's or guardian's bona fide religious beliefs and practices; or
if, because of a child's medical condition, the administration of an immunizing agent could precipitate a medical emergency.

section.heading: Commissioner to establish registry.
section.text: The Commissioner of Health is directed to adopt rules and regulations under § 2-106 {"Rules and regulations"} of this article to implement a registry of immunization history for children residing in the City.

annotations.annotation: Text conformed to include express cross-reference to § 2-106. Cf. Editor’s Note to that section.

para.heading: Duty to report.
para.text: Each pediatric, family, and general health care provider must report to the Commissioner whenever that provider administers an immunizing agent to any child who is less than 5 years old and resides in the City.

para.heading: When to report.
para.text: The report must be made within 14 days after administering the immunizing agent.

para.heading: Fine.
para.text: Any health care provider who violates any provision of this Part III or of a rule or regulation adopted under it is subject to a civil penalty of not more than $1,000 for each violation.

para.heading: Withholding assistance; records audit.
para.text: In addition to imposing a fine, the court may:
issue an order for withholding publicly distributed vaccines or pediatric primary care funding or both vaccines and funding; and
order the Department to conduct a medical records audit of the health care provider, the cost of the audit to be paid by the health care provider.

para.heading: Subtitle 9 inapplicable.
para.text: Subtitle 9 {"Penalties"} of this title does not apply to violations of this Part III.

section.heading: Parental responsibility.
section.text: Except as specified in § 4-603 {"Exceptions"} of this subtitle, every parent and guardian must provide for the timely and appropriate testing for lead poisoning of his or her minor children, as specified by the rules and regulations that the Commissioner adopts under § 2-106 {"Rules and regulations"} of this article.

annotations.annotation: Text conformed to include express cross-reference to § 2-106. Cf. Editor’s Note to that section.

section.heading: Provider's responsibility.
section.text: Except as specified in § 4-603 {"Exceptions"} of this subtitle, every pediatric and primary care health provider must order the timely and appropriate testing for lead poisoning of his or her minor patients, as specified by the rules and regulations that the Commissioner adopts under § 2-106 {"Rules and regulations"} of this article.

annotations.annotation: Text conformed to include express cross-reference to § 2-106. Cf. Editor’s Note to that section.

section.heading: Exceptions.
section.text: This Part I does not apply to any child whose parent or guardian, in accordance with the rules and regulations of the State Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene, objects to testing on the ground that it conflicts with the parent's or guardian's bona fide religious beliefs and practices.

para.heading: Separate offenses.
para.text: In enforcing this Part I, each child who is not properly tested as required is considered a separate violation.

para.heading: Civil penalties — Parents and guardians.
para.text: § 4-601{"Parental responsibility"} of this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of an environmental citation under Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"} of the City Code.

para.heading: Civil penalties — Providers.
para.text: Any provider who violates any provision of § 4-602 {"Provider's responsibility"} of this subtitle or of a rule or regulation adopted under it is subject to a civil penalty of not more than $100 for each violation.

para.heading: Subtitle 9 inapplicable.
para.text: Subtitle 9 {"Penalties"} of this title does not apply to violations of this Part I.

section.heading: Commissioner to establish registry.
section.text: The Commissioner of Health is directed to adopt rules and regulations under § 2-106 {"Rules and regulations"} of this article to implement a registry of screening history for children residing in the City.

annotations.annotation: Text conformed to include express cross-reference to § 2-106. Cf. Editor’s Note to that section.

para.heading: Duty to report.
para.text: Each medical laboratory must report to the Commissioner whenever that laboratory tests for lead poisoning any child who is less than 7 years old and who resides in the City.

para.heading: When to report.
para.text: The report must:
be made within 14 days after the test is conducted; and
contain the information that the Commissioner requires, as specified by the Commissioner's rules and regulations.
In this section, "child care facility" means any facility that:
provides for the care, custody, or control of a minor child; and
is required to be licensed by or registered with the State for that purpose.
Subject to the criteria contained in paragraph (1) of this subsection, "Child care facility" includes any:
child care center;
child care home;
child care institution;
family day care home;
non-public nursery school; or
non-public kindergarten.

para.heading: Duty to report.
para.text: Each child care facility must report to the Commissioner whenever that facility receives a State Health Inventory or other report that contains information on whether a child who resides in the City has been tested for lead poisoning.

para.heading: When to report.
para.text: The report must:
be made within 14 days after the State Health Inventory or other report is received by the facility; and
contain the information that the Commissioner requires, as specified by the Commissioner's rules and regulations.

para.heading: Fine.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this Part II or of a rule or regulation adopted under it is subject to a civil penalty of not more than $100 for each violation.

para.heading: Subtitle 9 inapplicable.
para.text: Subtitle 9 {"Penalties"} of this title does not apply to violations of this Part II.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Every 2 years, the Health Commissioner shall test all activated water fountains at each of 10 randomly-selected public schools.

para.heading: Expenses.
para.text: Testing shall be conducted at the expense of the Baltimore City School System.

section.heading: Failing fountains.
section.text: Any water fountain that fails to meet EPA standards must be taken out of service.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Suspect symptoms.
para.text: "Suspect symptoms" means those symptoms that, by rule or regulation adopted under § 2-106 of this article, the Commissioner designates as being indicative of a possible biological terrorist attack.

annotations.annotation: Text conformed to include express cross-reference to § 2-106. Cf. Editor’s Note to that section.

para.heading: When reports to be made.
para.text: Unless the Commissioner's rules or regulations specify otherwise, each report required by this subtitle must be made daily for all events occurring within the preceding 24 hours.

para.heading: How reports to be made.
para.text: Each report required by this subtitle must be made electronically, by a method and in the form the Commissioner's rules or regulations specify.

para.heading: Contents of reports.
para.text: Each report required by this subtitle must contain:
all of the information specified in this subtitle for that report; and
all other information that the Commissioner requires by rule or regulation.

para.heading: Duty to report.
para.text: The Emergency Medical System of the Baltimore City Fire Department must report to the Commissioner on all calls made to assist individuals who evidence suspect symptoms.

para.heading: Contents of report.
para.text: In addition to any other information required by rule or regulation, the report must specify for each reporting period:
the aggregate number of calls subject to the report; and
for each of these calls, the specific suspect symptom or symptoms identified.

para.heading: Duty to report.
para.text: The Department of Public Works, the Department of Transportation, and the Health Department's Bureau of Animal Control must report to the Commissioner on animal carcasses that the Commissioner specifies by rule or regulation.

para.heading: Contents of report.
para.text: In addition to any other information required by rule or regulation, the report must specify for each reporting period:
the aggregate number of carcasses subject to the report; and
the number of carcasses for each species.

para.heading: Duty to report.
para.text: The Baltimore City Public School System must report to the Commissioner on all elementary school absences.

para.heading: Contents of report.
para.text: In addition to any other information required by rule or regulation, the report must specify for each reporting period:
the aggregate percentage of absences Citywide; and
the percentage of absences by grade.

para.heading: Duty to report.
para.text: The Baltimore City Community Health Centers must report to the Commissioner on all patients who evidence suspect symptoms.

para.heading: Contents of report.
para.text: In addition to any other information required by rule or regulation, the report must specify for each reporting period:
the aggregate number of patients subject to the report; and
for each of these patients, the specific suspect symptom or symptoms identified.

para.heading: Duty to report.
para.text: The reporting officer of each hospital, related institution, clinic, or other health care facility, as appointed under § 4-202 of this title, must report to the Commissioner on all emergency department visits by individuals who evidence suspect symptoms.

para.heading: Contents of report.
para.text: In addition to any other information required by rule or regulation, the report must specify for each reporting period:
the aggregate number of patients subject to the report; and
for each of these patients, the specific suspect symptom or symptoms identified.

para.heading: Duty to report.
para.text: The individual in charge of any public or private pharmacy must report to the Commissioner on all sales of any over-the-counter medication that the Commissioner designates by rule or regulation as being a medication used for the treatment of suspect symptoms.

para.heading: Contents of report.
para.text: In addition to any other information required by rule or regulation, the report must specify, for each medication sold during a reporting period:
the type and strength of that index medication; and
the aggregate number of units sold during the reporting period.

section.heading: Violation a misdemeanor.
section.text: Except as otherwise specified in this title, any person who violates any provision of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to the penalties provided in this subtitle.

section.heading: Basic penalty: $1,000 and 12 months.
section.text: Except as otherwise specified in this title, the penalty for a violation of this title is a fine of not more than $1,000 or imprisonment for not more than 12 months or both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

section.heading: Failure to vaccinate: $500.
section.text: The penalty for a violation of § 4-503 {"Parental responsibility"} of this title is a fine of not more than $500 for each offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this title, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Nuisance.
para.text: "Nuisance" includes any of the following, whether or not otherwise regulated by federal, state, or local law:
garbage, rubbish, or other waste, as these terms are defined in Title 7 {"Waste Control"} of this article;
vermin infestations or other unsanitary conditions;
water or other liquid leaks or spills; or
any other health or safety hazard.

para.heading: Person in charge.
para.text: "Person in charge", when used with reference to any property, means all persons who own that property or who have possession, charge, care, or control of that property, whether as a personal representative, trustee, guardian, agent, or otherwise, and whether alone or jointly with any other person.
"Property" means all forms of real and personal property and possessions,
"Property" includes lots, structures, streets, wharves, docks, and other places.

section.heading: Commissioner's duties.
section.text: The Commissioner of Health is responsible for:

para.text: inspecting all property in the City, as the Commissioner considers necessary or appropriate to discover nuisances; and
requiring the removal of all nuisances so discovered.

section.heading: Responsibility of persons in charge.
section.text: Every person in charge of any property is obligated, jointly and severally with all other persons in charge of that property, to:

para.text: remove or abate all nuisances on or originating from the property; and
comply with all health- or safety-related laws that affect the property.

section.heading: Notice to persons in charge.
section.text: Whenever the Commissioner of Health discovers a condition that the Commissioner considers to be a nuisance or potential nuisance, the Commissioner may issue a written notice to one or more of the following persons or their respective agents:

para.text: the person in charge of the property on which the condition exists;
the person in charge of the property from which the condition originates; and
the person in charge of any property that fronts on the street in which the condition exists.

section.heading: Contents of notice.
section.text: A notice issued under this subtitle must:

para.text: identify the property and the condition;
specify the law being violated;
specify the corrective action to be taken;
state the time within which that action must be taken; and
state that, if corrective action is not timely taken:
the Commissioner may do the needed work; and
all costs and expenses will be a lien on the property.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A notice issued under this subtitle may be served by personal service or by certified mail, return receipt requested.

para.heading: Posting or publication.
para.text: If the person to be served cannot be found, the Commissioner may:
post the notice on the property; or
publish the notice in a newspaper of general circulation in the City.

section.heading: Abatement by Commissioner.
section.text: If the condition is not corrected within the time specified in the notice, the Commissioner may proceed to remove or abate the condition at the expense of the person in charge of the property.

para.heading: Person in charge liable.
para.text: The person in charge is liable to the City for all costs and expenses incurred in:
removing or abating the condition identified in the notice; and
posting or publishing notice under § 5-204 {"Service of notice"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: Costs and expenses as lien.
para.text: Until paid in full, these costs and expenses are a lien on the entire property from which the condition was removed or abated.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of an environmental citation as authorized by City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of an environmental citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

section.heading: Penalties: $1,000.
section.text: Any person in charge who refuses, neglects, or otherwise fails to comply with a notice issued under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 for each offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
"Dwelling" has the meaning stated in § 202.2 of the Baltimore City Building Code.
"Dwelling" includes any dwelling unit or rooming unit.

para.heading: Dwelling unit.
para.text: "Dwelling unit" has the meaning stated in § 202.2 of the Baltimore City Building Code.

para.heading: Rooming unit.
para.text: "Rooming unit" has the meaning stated in § 202.2 of the Baltimore City Property Maintenance Code.

section.heading: Scope of subtitle.
section.text: This subtitle applies only to dwellings and does not in any way modify or affect the authority of the Commissioner of Health to enter and inspect any building, structure, or premises other than a dwelling.

section.heading: Enforcement of Maintenance Code.
section.text: The Commissioner may:

para.text: enforce all provisions of the Baltimore City Property Maintenance Code; and
issue violation notices and orders under that Code to:
abate, remove, or otherwise deal with nuisances and emergencies affecting the public health; and
maintain and augment public health programs, such as rodent control, lead paint poisoning prevention, environmental sanitation, and housing hygiene.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Whenever the Commissioner has reason to believe that a nuisance exists in any dwelling, the Commissioner has the same authority to enter and inspect that dwelling as does the Commissioner of Housing and Community Development.

para.heading: Procedures.
para.text: The entry and inspection of a dwelling must comply with the requirements of § 2-107 {"Right of entry"} of this article.

para.heading: "Related law" defined.
para.text: In this section, "related law" has the meaning stated in § 104.6.2 {"Authority to seek warrant"} of the Baltimore City Building Code.

para.heading: Limit on testimony.
para.text: No inspector who gains entrance to a dwelling for the purpose of investigating a nuisance may obtain or furnish evidence of, or testify to, any offense other than:
a violation of this article or of any related law;
a felony; or
a misdemeanor involving an act of violence that is committed in the inspector's presence.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Lead-based paint.
para.text: "Lead-based paint" has the meaning stated in § 6-801(j) of the State Environment Article.

section.heading: Warning label required.
section.text: No person may possess, offer for sale, sell, or give away in the City any lead-based paint unless it bears the following or substantially equivalent warning:
"Warning — Contains Lead. Harmful if Eaten. Do not apply on any interior surfaces of a dwelling, or of a place used for the care of children, or on window sills, toys, cribs, or other furniture."

section.heading: Placement.
section.text: The warning required by this subtitle must:

para.text: appear in a conspicuous place on the paint's immediate container;
form an integral part of the printed label on that container; and
be printed in letters that are legible and that conspicuously contrast with any other printing on the container.

section.heading: Labels not to indicate interior use.
section.text: No label on a container of lead-based paint may indicate in any way that the product is suitable for interior surfaces of dwellings or for interior surfaces of any places used for the care of children.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of an environmental citation as authorized by City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of an environmental citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

section.heading: Penalties: $1,000.
section.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 for each offense.

section.heading: Spitting in public places.
section.text: No person may spit on:

para.text: any footpath or sidewalk of any public street or public square;
the floor or anywhere else in any public building under the control of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore;
the floor, platform, or steps of any railroad, bus, or other common carrier or of any depot or station;
the floor or steps of any theater, store, factory, or other building that is used in common by the public;
the floor of any hall or office used in common by the guests of a hotel or lodging house.

section.heading: Urinating or defecating in public places — in general.
section.text: No person may urinate or defecate on or about:

para.text: any public place, way, or park; or
the mall or adjacent parking area of any shopping center.

section.heading: Urinating or defecating in public places — parents or guardians of minors.
section.text: A parent or guardian may not knowingly permit a minor for whom the parent or guardian is responsible to violate § 5-503 {"Urinating or defecating in public places — in general"} of this subtitle.

section.heading: Minors urinating or defecating in public.

para.heading: Order to stop.
para.text: A police officer who finds any minor violating § 5-503 {"Urinating or defecating in public places — in general"} of this subtitle must order the minor to stop the violation.
If the minor fails to comply with the order, the police officer may take him or her into custody.
After the information needed to carry out the purposes of this subtitle has been recorded, the minor must be:
promptly released to his or her parent or guardian, with written notice to the parent or guardian of the violation; and
referred to the Baltimore City Police Department's court sanctioned pre-intake adjustment program.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: Spitting: $25/ $50.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of § 5-501 {"Spitting in public places"} of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to:
for a first offense, a fine of not more than $25; and
for a second and any subsequent offense, a fine of not more than $50.

para.heading: Urinating or defecating — adult offenders: $500 and 30 days.
para.text: Any adult who violates § 5-503 {"Urinating or defecating in public places — in general"} of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or to imprisonment for not more than 30 days or to both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: Urinating or defecating — parent or guardian of minor: $200.
para.text: Any parent or guardian who violates § 5-504 {"Urinating or defecating in public places — parents or guardians of minors"} of this subtitle within 12 months after receiving written notice of the minor's having violated § 5-504 {"Urinating or defecating in public places — in general"} of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $200 for each offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
"Collection of water" means any collection of standing or running water.

"Collection of water" includes water contained in any ditch, roof or other gutter, pond, pool, excavation, depression, fountain, tank, well, barrel, tire, urn, can, box, bottle, tub, bucket, or other similar container.

section.heading: Purpose of subtitle.
section.text: The purpose of this subtitle is to get rid of the discomfort, annoyance, and health hazards that are caused by mosquitoes.

section.heading: Responsibility of persons in charge.
section.text: Every person in charge of any property is obligated, jointly and severally, to comply with the requirements of this subtitle.

section.heading: Collections prohibited unless treated.
section.text: No person in charge may keep or permit to be kept any collection of water in which mosquitoes are likely to breed, unless the collection of water is treated to effectively prevent breeding.

section.heading: Methods of treatment.
section.text: The method for treating a collection of water to prevent mosquitoes from breeding must be one or more of the following:

para.text: emptying all water at least once every 5 days;
using a larvicide approved by and applied in accordance with the requirements of the United States Environmental Protection Agency;

cleaning and keeping the water free of vegetable growth and other obstructions and stocking with mosquito-destroying fish (the absence of half-grown or larger mosquito larvae to be evidence of having complied with this method);
filling or draining to the satisfaction of the Commissioner of Health;
removing, at least once every 5 days, all tin cans, tin boxes, broken or empty bottles, and similar articles likely to hold water;
screening with wire netting of at least 16 meshes to the inch each way;
screening with any other material that will prevent the ingress or egress of mosquitoes; or
any other method that the Commissioner approves.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The natural presence of mosquito larvae in standing or running water is evidence that mosquitoes are breeding there.

para.heading: Required action.
para.text: Within 5 days of notice from the Commissioner, the person in charge of the premises must act to prevent further breeding.

section.heading: Notice to person in charge.
section.text: Whenever the Commissioner discovers a condition that could give rise to the breeding of mosquitoes, the Commissioner must issue a written notice to the person in charge, as provided in Subtitle 2 {"Nuisance Abatement — Generally"} of this title.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: If the condition is not corrected within 10 days of the notice, the Commissioner may proceed to correct the condition at the expense of the person in charge.

para.heading: Costs and expenses.
para.text: All costs and expenses incurred by the Commissioner are a lien on the property as provided in Subtitle 2 {"Nuisance Abatement — Generally"} of this title.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who refuses, neglects, or otherwise fails to comply with a notice issued under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $500 for each offense.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day that a violation continues is a separate offense.

section.heading: Responsibility of persons in charge.
section.text: Every person in charge of any property is obligated, jointly and severally, to comply with the requirements of this subtitle.

section.heading: Cutting grass, weeds, etc., required.
section.text: No person in charge of any land may allow:

para.text: any grass, weeds, or other rank vegetation on that land to reach a height of 8 inches or more; or
any grass, weeds, or other rank vegetation on an abutting sidewalk, gutter, or alley to reach a height of 4 inches or more.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Every person in charge of any land must keep that land free from ragweeds, wild mustard, wild lettuce, wild parsley, common thistle, milkweed, poison ivy, and all other noxious weeds.

para.heading: Permitted methods.
para.text: The person in charge must destroy any noxious weeds on the land by:
spraying with a chemical compound approved by and applied in accordance with the requirements of the United States Environmental Protection Agency;
cutting and removal;
digging under; or
any other method that the Commissioner approves.

section.heading: Notice to person in charge.
section.text: Whenever the Commissioner of Health discovers a violation of this subtitle, the Commissioner may issue a written notice to the person in charge, as provided in Subtitle 2 {"Nuisance Abatement — Generally"} of this title.

para.text: If the condition is not corrected within 10 days of the notice, the Commissioner may notify the Director of Public Works, who must proceed to correct the condition at the expense of the person in charge.
Grass, weeds, and other rank vegetation must be cut to a height of not more than 3 inches.

para.heading: Costs and expenses.
para.text: All costs and expenses incurred by the Director of Public Works are a lien on the property as provided in Subtitle 2 {"Nuisance Abatement — Generally"} of this title.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of an environmental citation as authorized by City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of an environmental citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to the penalties specified in this section.

para.heading: Basic penalty: $500.
para.text: Except as specified in subsection (c) of this section, the penalty for a violation is a fine of not more than $500 for each offense.

para.heading: Violation after notice: $1,000.
para.text: For a person who receives a notice under §5-704 {"Notice to person in charge"} of this subtitle and fails to comply with that notice, the penalty is a fine of not more than $1,000 for each offense.

section.heading: Cleaning sidewalks and gutters.
section.text: The person in charge of any premises or lot must keep the sidewalk and gutters bounding on the premises or lot open and free from waste or obstructions and clean at all times.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: No person may use or keep on that person's property any liquid or solid matter that is or that, after exposure to the atmosphere or otherwise, is likely to become offensive or otherwise a nuisance.

para.heading: Illustrations.
para.text: This section applies to, among other things, any:
blood;
refuse coal oil;
dead animal or part of an animal;
domestic or sanitary sewage;
excrement;
filth;
foul or nauseous liquid;
garbage;
slaughter house or other trade cleanings;
stagnant water; or
other offensive matter of any kind.

section.heading: Livestock.
section.text: Every person who keeps a cow, horse, or other livestock in the City must keep the animal and its stable or other housing in such a way that no filth or stench becomes offensive to or annoys any neighbor or other person.

section.heading: Deposit on streets, etc. prohibited.
section.text: No person may place or cause or allow to be placed on any street any noxious or objectionable matter that from its acid content or otherwise might be injurious or harmful to any person or to the clothing, household furnishings, or personal effects of any person.

para.heading: "Plastic bag" defined.
para.text: "Plastic bag" means any bag that is:
intended for household use or for packaging garments or other articles intended for household use;
larger than 6 inches in diameter at the open end; and
made of film less than 1 mil (0.001 inch) thick.

para.heading: Printed warning required.
para.text: No person may package, deliver, or sell in a plastic bag any article for use in or around the household or sell or distribute any plastic bag for use in or around the household unless the bag bears a warning as required by this section.

para.heading: Text of warning.
para.text: The warning must warn the consumer against the hazard of suffocation by children in the following or substantially equivalent wording:

include.text: "Warning: To avoid danger of suffocation, keep away from babies and children. Do not use in cribs, beds, carriages, or playpens. This bag is not a toy."

para.text: The warning must be printed on, attached to, or accompany each plastic bag or each package of plastic bags delivered to the consumer.
The warning must be prominently and conspicuously displayed in bold face type, in accordance with the following table:

tr.th: Combined length and width of bag

tr.td: 30 inches or more, but less than 40 inches
40 inches or more, but less than 60 inches

section.heading: Abandoned refrigerators, etc.
section.text: No person may place or permit anyone else to place in any location that is outside of a dwelling or other building and accessible to children any abandoned, unattended, or uncrated ice box, refrigerator, or freezer cabinet equipped with a door or lock that cannot be opened from the inside.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to the penalties specified in this section.

para.heading: Basic penalty: $500.
para.text: Except as otherwise specified in this section, the penalty for a violation is a fine of not more than $500 for each offense.

para.heading: Violation after notice: $1,000.
para.text: For a person who receives a notice under Subtitle 2 of this title to correct a violation of any provision of this subtitle and fails to comply with that notice, the penalty is a fine of not more than $1,000 for each offense.

For a person who violates any provision of § 5-906 {"Abandoned refrigerators, etc."} of this subtitle, the penalty is a fine of not more than $500 or imprisonment for not more than 30 days or both fine and imprisonment for each offense.
Each day that a violation of § 5-906 continues is a separate offense.

para.heading: In general.
