section.heading: Penalties: $500.
section.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $500 for each offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: License.
para.text: "License" means a license issued under this subtitle to operate a landfill.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Person" has the meaning stated in § 1-107(a) {"Person: In general"} of the City Code's General Provisions Article.

para.heading: Qualified inclusion of governmental entities.
para.text: Notwithstanding § 1-107(b) {"Person: Exclusion"} of the General Provisions Article, in this subtitle "person" also includes, except as used in § 7-419 {"Penalties"} of this subtitle, a governmental entity or an instrumentality or unit of a governmental entity.

section.heading: Exceptions from subtitle.
section.text: This subtitle does not apply to:

para.text: the random placement of broken stones or rubble as a foundation, sustaining wall, or similar structure to control erosion; or
to the otherwise lawful filling of land exclusively with earth fill material that contains:
no more than 10% organic matter or rubble by volume; and
no object larger than 12 inches in any dimension.

section.heading: In general.
section.text: No person may operate a landfill in the City without a license to do so from the Commissioner of Health.

section.heading: Applications.
section.text: The application for a license:

para.text: must be on the form that the Commissioner provides; and
in addition to any other information that the Commissioner requires, must contain:
the name of the applicant;
the applicant's home address;
the address of the applicant's principal place of business;
the location of the proposed landfill;
the name under which the business is carried on;
a detailed engineering plan of the proposed operation of the landfill; and
evidence satisfactory to the Commissioner that the applicant has obtained a bond or other security, running to the benefit of the City, in the form, amount, and tenor:
as required by State law for landfills licensed by the State; or
if no bond or security is required by State law, as the Commissioner requires.

section.heading: Issuance of license.
section.text: The Commissioner must issue a license to the applicant if:

para.text: the Commissioner approves the engineering plan;
the applicant has complied with all applicable laws, rules, and regulations; and
the applicant pays the applicable fee.

para.heading: Term of license.
para.text: Unless sooner suspended or revoked, a license expires annually on the anniversary of its effective date.

para.heading: Application for renewal.
para.text: Before a license expires, the licensee periodically may renew the license for an additional 1-year term, if the licensee:
otherwise is entitled to a license;
submits a renewal application to the Commissioner, in the form that the Commissioner requires; and
pays the applicable renewal fee.

section.heading: License fees.
section.text: The annual fee for a license is as set by the Commissioner, with the approval of the Board of Estimates.

section.heading: Notice of changed information.
section.text: A licensee must immediately notify the Commissioner of any change in any of the information contained in or accompanying the licensee's application for a license or a renewal.

para.heading: Grounds.
para.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of Title 2, Subtitle 3 {"Administrative Hearings"} of this article, the Commissioner of Health may suspend a license:
on receipt of notice of intent to cancel the bond or other security required by State law;
if the licensee fails to comply with the engineering plan approved by the Commissioner; or
if the Commissioner finds the licensee has caused a condition that is hazardous to the public health, safety, or welfare.

para.heading: Duration.
para.text: A suspension continues until the licensee:
satisfies the Commissioner that the cause for the suspension has been adequately corrected; and
has reimbursed the City for any expenses that the City incurs as a result of the condition.

section.heading: Revocations and denials of renewal.
section.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of Title 2, Subtitle 3 {"Administrative Hearings"} of this article, the Commissioner of Health may revoke or refuse to renew the license of any licensee who repeatedly violates any of the conditions of the license or any of the provisions of this subtitle or of the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

section.heading: Penalties: $1,000 and $100/day.
section.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle or of a rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 for each offense, plus $100 for each day that the offense continues.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Flow back.
para.text: "Flow back" means the fracturing fluids that return to the surface after a hydraulic fracture is completed.

para.heading: Hydraulic fracturing.
para.text: "Hydraulic fracturing" means the drilling technique (also known colloquially as "fracking", "hydrofracking", or "hydrofracturing") of expanding or creating fractures in rock by injecting fluids, often a mixture of water and chemicals, sand, or other substances, and often under pressure, into or underneath the surface of the rock for various purposes, including well drilling and natural gas exploration and production.

section.heading: Hydraulic fracturing prohibited
section.text: No person may make use of hydraulic fracturing to extract oil, gas, or other hydrocarbons within the City of Baltimore.

section.heading: Storing, treating, disposing, etc., wastewater prohibited.
section.text: No person may store, treat, discharge, or dispose of in the City or in or on any City-owned facility or property, wherever situated, any flow back or other wastewater resulting from hydraulic fracturing.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000, imprisonment for not more than 90 days, or both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day that a violation continues is a separate offense.

section.heading: "Litter" excluded.
section.text: This subtitle does not apply to the disposal of "litter", as defined in Subtitle 7 of this title.

section.heading: In general.
section.text: No person may dispose of any waste or other material except:

para.text: in a receptacle and at a location approved by law for waste disposal;
at a licensed landfill; or
at any other disposal site authorized by law to receive waste.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: No person may dispose of or permit to discharge or flow onto any public or private property, with or without the owner's permission, any liquid or solid matter that is or that, after exposure to the atmosphere or otherwise, is likely to become offensive or otherwise a nuisance.

para.heading: Illustrations.
para.text: This section applies to, among other things, any:
blood;
refuse coal oil;
dead animal or part of an animal;
domestic or sanitary sewage;
excrement;
filth;
foul or nauseous liquid;
garbage;
slaughter house or other trade cleanings;
stagnant water; or
offensive matter of any kind.

section.heading: Dumping on public property.
section.text: No person may dump or dispose of any garbage, waste, wire, glass, nails, or any other matter:

para.text: in or on any gutter, sidewalk, street, open space, wharf, or other public place; or
except for litter, as defined in Subtitle 7 of this title, into any public trash receptacle located on or along any sidewalk, street, open space, wharf, or other public place.

section.heading: Dumping on private property.
section.text: No person may dump or otherwise dispose of any earth, dirt, sand, ashes, gravel, rocks, garbage, waste, or any other matter on any private property, including in or near any waste receptacle on the property, without the permission of the property owner or the owner's agent.

section.heading: Burning waste.
section.text: No person may burn or cause to be burned any garbage or other waste except as specifically authorized by law.

section.heading: Responsibility of vehicle owner.
section.text: The registered owner of a vehicle or, for a leased or rented vehicle, the lessee or renter, as identified on the lease or rental agreement, is prima facie responsible for any waste or other material transported in or disposed of from that vehicle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, any vehicle used for or in connection with disposing waste or other material in violation of this subtitle is subject to seizure and forfeiture.

para.heading: Unauthorized possession or use of vehicle.
para.text: A vehicle may not be forfeited under this subtitle solely because of an act or omission by a person other than the vehicle's owner committed or omitted:
while the vehicle was unlawfully in that other person's possession; or

while the vehicle was lawfully in that other person's possession, but the owner can establish by a preponderance of the evidence that the violation of this subtitle was committed without the owner's actual knowledge.

para.heading: When warrant not needed.
para.text: A police officer need not have a warrant to seize a vehicle if:
the police officer has probable cause to believe the vehicle has been used in violation of this subtitle; and
a warrant is not constitutionally required under the circumstances.

para.heading: Removal of vehicle.
para.text: Whenever a police officer seizes a vehicle under this subtitle, the police officer may cause it to be moved to a place designated by the Police Commissioner.

para.heading: Vehicle not repleviable.
para.text: A vehicle seized under this subtitle is not repleviable and remains in the custody of the Police Department, subject only to the orders and decrees of the court or official with jurisdiction over it.

para.heading: Police to refer case.
para.text: Promptly after seizure, the Police Department must notify the City Solicitor in writing of the facts and circumstances supporting the seizure.
On receiving the report, the Solicitor must conduct an independent review of the facts and circumstances surrounding the seizure.

If the Solicitor finds sufficient evidence that the vehicle was used in violation of this subtitle, the Solicitor must notify the vehicle's owner, by registered or certified mail, of the seizure and of the City's intent to institute forfeiture proceedings.
If, on the other hand, the Solicitor finds that there is insufficient evidence to prove violation, the Solicitor must surrender the vehicle to the owner on the owner's request.

para.heading: Filing; copies to parties in interest.
para.text: If the Solicitor determines that the vehicle should be forfeited, the Solicitor must, within 90 days after the seizure of the vehicle:
petition the Circuit Court for Baltimore City in the name of the City against the vehicle, as designated by make, model, year, and motor or serial number; and
at the same time, send by registered or certified mail and by first class mail to the owner and any known secured party:
copies of the petition; and
a notice of the time and place for a response to be filed.

para.heading: Contents.
para.text: The petition for forfeiture must contain:
the name of the registered owners of the vehicle;
the name of any secured party;
a statement of the facts and circumstances surrounding the seizure of the vehicle;
a statement of the specific grounds for forfeiture; and
a request that the vehicle be forfeited to the City.
Within 7 days of the petition's filing, the Solicitor must publish notice of the seizure and forfeiture proceeding in 1 or more newspapers published in the City.
The notice must:
state the substance and object of the forfeiture petition; and
state that any person claiming an interest in the seized vehicle must file a defense to the petition within 15 days of the date of the notice.

para.heading: When to be made.
para.text: Any defense to the petition must be filed within 15 days after publication of the notice.
All defenses to a petition for forfeiture must be made by answer.
The answer must:
comply with the Maryland Rules of Procedure as to form and contents;
be divided into numbered paragraphs, each containing a separate and distinctive averment; and

respond to each material allegation contained in the petition, specifically admitting, denying, or explaining the facts alleged, unless the respondent is without knowledge or an admission or explanation would tend to incriminate the respondent, in either of which events the respondent must so state and that statement will operate as a denial.
Every allegation in the petition that is not denied in the answer is considered admitted, except as to persons unknown.
New or affirmative matter alleged in the answer is considered denied or avoided by the petitioner without the need of any replication, unless the court orders otherwise.
If the owner of the seized vehicle wants to repossess it before the petition is decided, the Clerk of the Circuit Court must have an appraisal made.
The appraisal must be in writing, under oath, to the Clerk of the Circuit Court.
When the appraisal is filed, the owner may post a bond, payable to the City, in an amount equal to:
all court costs that may accrue; plus
the greater of:
the appraised value of the vehicle;
the aggregate amount of the liens on the vehicle, as shown in the records required by law for the notice or perfection of liens; or

The bond must have security approved by the Clerk and be conditioned for performance on the final judgment of the Circuit Court. If a petition for forfeiture has been filed, the bond must be filed in the Circuit Court for Baltimore City.

para.heading: Judgment on bond.
para.text: If the court directs that the vehicle be forfeited, judgment may be entered against the obligors on the bond, without further or other proceeding, to be discharged by the payment of the appraised value of the vehicle and court costs, on which judgment execution may be issued.
If the court determines that the vehicle should be forfeited, the court must order the vehicle forfeited to the City.

If, however, the court determines that the vehicle is subject to a bona fide recorded security interest created without the knowledge that the vehicle was being or was to be used in violation of this subtitle, the court must order that the vehicle be released within 5 days to the secured party of record.

para.heading: Disposition of vehicle subject to security interest.

para.text: The secured party must sell the vehicle in a commercially reasonable manner.
Any sale ordered under this section must be made for cash and must vest in the purchaser a clear and absolute title to the vehicle.
The proceeds of the sale must be applied as follows:
to the court costs of the forfeiture proceedings;
to the balance due to the secured party, including all reasonable costs incident to the sale;
to payment of all other expenses of the proceedings for forfeiture, including expenses of seizure, maintenance, or custody; and
to the general funds of the City.

para.heading: Disposition of forfeited vehicle.
para.text: Any vehicle that has been ordered forfeited to the City may be:
sold as provided in City Code Article 31, Subtitle 31, Part 5; or
destroyed.

para.heading: Proceeds of bond.
para.text: The proceeds of any bond posted to regain possession of the vehicle must be applied as provided for proceeds of sale under subsection (b)(3) of this section.

section.heading: Order of release.
section.text: If, after a full hearing, the court determines that the vehicle should not be forfeited, the court must order the vehicle released.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The City Housing Commissioner must establish a grants program for rewarding community and neighborhood associations that have registered for this purpose with the Housing Commissioner and have been designated by citizens reporting illegal disposal or other violations of this subtitle.
Funds for these grants are as provided in the Ordinance of Estimates.

The amount of the grants, the criteria for allocating and awarding them, and the purposes for which they may be used are as set forth in the rules and regulations adopted by the Commissioner under § 2-106 {"Rules and regulations"} of this article.

annotations.annotation: Text conformed to include express cross-reference to § 2-106. Cf. Editor’s Note to that section.

section.heading: Liability for costs and expenses.
section.text: Any person who, in violation of § 7-608 {"Dumping on public property"} of this subtitle or in violation of any other provision of law, dumps or otherwise disposes of matter in or on property owned, leased, or controlled by the City is liable to the City for the costs of:

para.text: removing the matter dumped or disposed of; and
repairing any damage caused by the dumping or disposal.

section.heading: Enforcement by Environmental or Civil Citation.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: Basic penalty: $1,000 and 90 days.
para.text: Except as specified in subsection (b) of this section, any person who violates any provision of this subtitle or who authorizes any employee or agent to violate any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to any one or more of the following for each offense:
a fine of not more than $1,000; and
imprisonment for not more than 90 days.

para.heading: Enhanced penalty: $1,000 and 12 months.
para.text: If the violation entails the disposal, in any 24-hour period, of material that weighs 25 or more pounds or material that comprises 10 or more cubic feet, the penalty for a violation of this subtitle is any one or more of the following for each offense:
a fine of not more than $1,000;
imprisonment for not more than 12 months; and
revocation of the privilege of seeking a building permit in the City.

section.heading: "Litter" defined.
section.text: "Litter" means to discard or otherwise dispose of, in any way other than as authorized by § 7-601 of this title, of small amounts of paper, beverage containers, glass, garbage, or other waste that:

para.text: weigh less than 1 pound;
comprise less than 1 cubic foot; and
are not toxic, noxious, or otherwise a threat to the public health or safety.

section.heading: Littering prohibited.
section.text: No person may:

para.text: litter on any public or private property; or
permit the accumulation of litter on any property under that person's control.

section.heading: Material from vehicle.
section.text: The registered owner of a vehicle is prima facie responsible for any litter disposed of from that vehicle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of $500 for each offense.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day a violation continues is a separate offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Air pollution.
para.text: "Air pollution" means the presence in the outdoor atmosphere of any odor, solid, vapor, liquid, gas, or other substance in such quantities and of such duration that it:
can be predicted with reasonable certainty to be injurious to property or to human, plant, or animal life; or
unreasonably interferes with the proper enjoyment of the property of others or with the comfort of the public.
"Emission standard" means a requirement that limits the quantity, quality, rate, or concentration of emissions from a source.
"Emission standard" includes any requirement that relates to the operation or maintenance of a source to assure continuous emission reduction.

para.heading: Source.
para.text: "Source" means any equipment, process, structure, space, material, or activity that contributes to air pollution.

para.heading: Surveys, studies, etc.
para.text: The Commissioner of Health may undertake surveys, investigations, studies, and like activities to determine the condition of the air in the City and how best to improve that condition.

para.heading: Setting emission standards.
para.text: In the rules and regulations that the Commissioner adopts under § 2-106 {"Rules and regulations"} of this article, the Commissioner may set emission standards and adopt procedures for implementing and enforcing those standards.

section.heading: Prohibited conduct.
section.text: No person may operate or use any source, whether indoors or outdoors, static or mobile, that contributes to air pollution in any way or amount that exceeds emission standards:

para.text: set by federal or state law or regulation; or
set by the Commissioner.

section.heading: Order to correct conditions.
section.text: Whenever as the result of an investigation or study, the result of a complaint, or otherwise, the Commissioner of Health finds that any source is contributing to air pollution in excess of that permitted by law, the Commissioner may issue a written notice to the owner or operator of that source and order the owner or operator to remove or control the cause of the emission in the manner and within the time specified in the notice.

annotations.annotation: This Part II was added by Ordinance 19-232 (enacted March 7, 2019). Section 2 of that Ordinance provides that, except as otherwise provided in Section 3, the new law takes effect 18 months after the date of enactment (i.e., on September 7, 2020). Section 3, in turn, provides that “the Health Commissioner may begin to certify Air Monitoring Contractors in accordance with § 8-124 ... of this Ordinance on or after the date this Ordinance is enacted.”

para.heading: Short title.
para.text: This Part II shall be known and may be cited as the "Baltimore Clean Air Act"

para.heading: Purpose.
para.text: The purpose and intent of this Part II is to ensure that accurate and complete information is available to the City and general public about pollutants released from commercial solid waste incinerators within the City and to exercise the authority granted to the City under the Maryland Environment Code.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The following words and phrases when used within this Part II, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section.

para.heading: Air Monitoring Contractor.
para.text: "Air Monitoring Contractor" means an environmental engineer certified by the City to design, install, operate, and maintain the Continuous Emissions Monitoring Systems required by this Part II.

para.heading: Commercial solid waste incinerator; Facility.
para.text: "Commercial solid waste incinerator" or "facility" means any facility in Baltimore City that produces energy or disposes of waste by combusting a solid fuel or waste, or gases produced on-site from the gasification or pyrolysis of a solid fuel or waste, and that is capable of processing at least 25 tons of solid fuel or waste per day.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Continuous Emissions Monitoring System" or "CEMS" means a pollution monitoring system capable of sampling, conditioning, analyzing, and providing a record of emissions at frequent intervals that meets U.S. Environmental Protection Agency or Maryland Department of the Environment data acquisition and availability requirements.

para.heading: Sampling frequency.
para.text: Except as specified in paragraph (3) of this subsection, the sampling frequency capability sufficient to qualify a system as a CEMS for the purposes of this Part II must at a minimum deliver a monitoring sample:
once per minute; or

any lesser frequency of interval, up to no less than once per hour, that provides sufficient data for a direct determination of compliance with all applicable emission limitations imposed by this Part II.

para.heading: Dioxin and furan sampling.
para.text: In the case of dioxins and furans, long-term sampling equipment may be used if real-time monitors are not commercially available, so long as year-round monitoring is still achieved through back-to-back use of long-term monthly samples.

para.heading: Solid fuel; Waste.
para.text: "Solid fuel" or "waste" means any solid waste, discarded material, recyclable materials, sludges, by-products, commercial chemical products, municipal waste, hazardous waste, biomass, processed debris, special medical waste, sterilized special medical waste, sewage sludge, scrap tires, auto shredder residue, refuse-derived fuel, processed engineered fuel, or solid fuel produced from municipal waste.

para.heading: TEQDF-WHO98.
para.text: "TEQDF-WHO98" means a unit of measurement for dioxins and furans, standardized to toxic equivalents, calculated in accordance with the World Health Organization's 1998 method.

section.heading: Scope.
section.text: All commercial solid waste incinerators located within Baltimore City are subject to the requirements of this Part II.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: In the rules and regulations that the Commissioner adopts under § 2-106 {"Rules and regulations"} of this article, the Health Commissioner may adopt rules and regulations to implement this Part II.

annotations.annotation: Text conformed to include express cross-reference to § 2-106. Cf. Editor’s Note to that section.

section.heading: Pollutants to be continuously monitored.
section.text: Each facility must, at its own expense, contract with an Air Monitoring Contractor certified by the Health Commissioner in accordance with § 8-124 {"Certification of Air Monitoring Contractor"} to install, operate, and maintain Continuous Emissions Monitoring Systems ("CEMS") equipment to monitor, measure, and disclose the smokestack emission of the following pollutants:

para.text: Dioxins and Furans, as measured at a point, after all air pollution control devices, where the exhaust gases have cooled to below 200 degrees Centigrade;
Carbon Dioxide (CO2) and Carbon Monoxide (CO);
Hydrochloric Acid (HCl) and Hydrofluoric Acid (HF);
Nitrogen Oxides (NOx);
Sulfur Dioxides (SO2);
Particulate Matter (PM);
Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs);
Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons (PAHs); and
Arsenic, Cadmium, Chromium (VI), Lead, Manganese, Mercury, Nickel, Selenium, and Zinc.

section.heading: Monitoring system to be continuously active.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A facility's CEMS must be operational at all times that the facility is operating.

para.heading: Gaps of more than 30 minutes a violation.
para.text: CEMS downtime that exceeds 30 consecutive minutes while a facility is operating are a violation of this section.

para.heading: For Mercury and Sulfur Dioxide.
para.text: Each facility must meet the following pollution limits:

td.p: 15 micrograms per dry standard cubic meter (μg/dscm) corrected at 7% O2
18 parts per million dry volume (ppmvd) corrected at 7% O2 (24 hour geometric mean)

para.heading: Limits for Dioxins/Furans and Nitrogen Oxides.
para.text: Starting January 1, 2022, in addition to the limits imposed by subsection (b) of this section, each facility must meet the following pollution limits:

tr.td: 2.6 nanograms TEQDF-WHO98 per dry standard cubic meter (ng/dcsm) corrected at 7% O2

td.p: 45 parts per million dry volume (ppmvd) corrected at 7% O2 (24 hour block arithmetic mean)
40 parts per million dry volume (ppmvd) corrected at 7% O2 (12 month rolling average)

section.heading: City adoption and enforcement of more stringent Federal and State requirements.

para.heading: Adoption.
para.text: If the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency or the State of Maryland adopts a more stringent standard, limit, or requirement for the emission of air contaminants, a more stringent standard of performance for any facility regulated by this Part II, or a more stringent standard of performance for stationary sources that would apply to a facility than is imposed by this Part II, the facility must meet the more stringent requirement.

para.heading: Enforcement.
para.text: It is expressly the intent of the City in adopting the standards, limits, requirements, and standards of performance referenced in subsection (a) of this section to make those more stringent requirements independently enforceable by the City of Baltimore.
Each facility must provide a daily report to its Air Monitoring Contractor that details:
the daily emissions from the facility of the pollutants listed in § 8-114 {"Pollutants to be continuously monitored"} of this Part II; and
the reasons for any CEMS downtime.
All data supplied as part of the reports required by this section are property of the City of Baltimore.

para.heading: Form of report.
para.text: The daily report required by this section must be in the form specified by the Health Commissioner and include all relevant machine readable raw data.

para.heading: Reasonable access required.
para.text: A facility must provide reasonable access to its property and operations to the Air Monitoring Contractor responsible for preparing the reports required by this section to enable the reports to be prepared and verified.

para.heading: Historical reports.
para.text: Each facility must provide its Air Monitoring Contractor with all emissions reports for the facility previously provided to the Maryland Department of the Environment, and any prior Air Monitoring Contractor for the facility, at the time that the Air Monitoring Contractor begins monitoring the facility.

The Air Monitoring Contractor must disclose the information it receives in the daily reports required by § 8-120(a) {"Required CEMS reports: Reports required"} of this Part II to the public on a publicly accessible webpage capable of providing an easy to read graphical portrayal of the information.

The Air Monitoring Contractor must archive all of the daily reports received from a facility under § 8-120 {"Required CEMS reports"} of this Part II and make this archived historical data, together with all data provided by the facility under § 8-120(d) {"Required CEMS reports: Historical reports"}, available on a publicly accessible webpage capable of providing an easy to read graphical portrayal of the information.

para.heading: Reports to Health Department.
para.text: The Air Monitoring Contractor for a facility must provide reports to the Health Commissioner, in the form specified by the Commissioner and including all relevant machine readable raw data, about emissions from the facility:
whenever the facility exceeds an emission limit set under § 8-116 {"Emission limits"} or § 8-117 {"City adoption and enforcement of more stringent Federal and State requirements"};
at regular intervals set by the Commissioner; and
whenever requested by the Commissioner, or the Commissioner's designee.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Air Monitoring Contractor for a facility must periodically inspect the Continuous Emissions Monitoring Systems installed at the facility and verify that they are operating correctly.

para.heading: Times and intervals.
para.text: Inspections required by this section must take place at times and intervals chosen by the Health Commissioner and will not be announced in advance to the facility.

para.heading: Frequency.
para.text: No fewer than 4 inspections must be conducted each calendar year.

para.heading: Required capabilities.
para.text: In order to be certified as an Air Monitoring Contractor, an applicant must demonstrate to the Health Commissioner's satisfaction that it, using its own resources or in partnership with 1 or more co-applicants, is capable of:
procuring or developing, and thereafter installing, CEMS equipment at a subject facility;
performing regular inspections as required by§ 8-122 {"Inspections"} of this Part II; and
developing software utilities capable of capturing and publically displaying CEMS data needed for the daily reports required by § 8-120 {"Required CEMS reports"} of this Part II.

para.heading: Conflicts of interests.
para.text: In order to be certified as an Air Monitoring Contractor, an applicant must not have had a contract, other than a contract to perform the duties of an Air Monitoring Contractor under this Part II, with a facility, or the owner or operator of a facility:
within the past 10 years; or
for the duration of their role as an Air Monitoring Contractor.

para.heading: Certification.
para.text: No later than 6 months after the effective date of this Ordinance, the Baltimore City Health Department shall certify an applicant meeting the requirements of subsections (a) and (b) of this section as an Air Monitoring Contractor within 90 days of receiving:
information, in the form required by the Health Commissioner, sufficient to demonstrate that the applicant meets the requirements of subsections (a) and (b) of this section; and
payment of the application fee set by the Board of Estimates.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this Part II, or of a rule or regulation adopted under this Part II, is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or imprisonment for not more than 90 days or both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: Multiple simultaneous violations.
para.text: If a person is responsible for simultaneous violations of more than 1 section of this Part II, simultaneously failing to monitor, measure, and disclose the emission of more than 1 pollutant as required by § 8-114 {"Pollutants to be continuously monitored"} of this Part II, or simultaneously violating more than 1 standard required by § 8-116 {"Emission limits"} of this Part II, each separate violation constitutes a separate offense.

para.heading: Continuing violations.
para.text: Each day that a violation continues constitutes a separate offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Open burning.
para.text: "Open burning" means any fire or smoke-producing process that emits particulates or gases directly into the atmosphere without passing through any air pollution control equipment.

para.heading: Waste.
para.text: "Waste" has the meaning stated in §7-101 of this article.

para.heading: Findings and policy.
para.text: Because open burning can be a major contributor to air pollution in Baltimore City, the City's policy is to eliminate or control pollution from open burning to protect the health, welfare, and property of the people of the City.

para.heading: Commissioner to regulate.
para.text: For this reason, the Commissioner of Health may regulate open burning.

section.heading: Open burning prohibited.
section.text: Except as specified in § 8-204 {"Exceptions"} of this subtitle, no person may permit or carry on any open burning of waste.

para.heading: Outdoor cooking.
para.text: The use of outdoor grills and fireplaces to prepare food is permitted unless prohibited by the Fire Department.

para.heading: Disposal of explosives.
para.text: The open burning of highly explosive or other dangerous materials for which there is no other known method of disposal or under other unusual circumstances is permitted if, on written request, the burning is:
approved by the Commissioner and the Chief of the Fire Department; and
done under the supervision of the Fire Department.

para.heading: Training.
para.text: The open burning of solid, liquid, or gaseous fuels, materials, or buildings is permitted if done for training purposes under the direct control and supervision of Fire Department instructors.

para.heading: Salamanders, etc.
para.text: Unless prohibited by the Fire Department, the use of salamanders or similar devices by construction or other workers for heat is permitted if:
no smoke violation or other nuisance is created; and
the salamander or other device is of a type approved by the Chief of the Fire Department.

para.heading: Emergencies.
para.text: In an emergency declared by the Commissioner, the open burning of household and normal business waste is permitted if it is done in compliance with the conditions and requirements that the Commissioner specifies for the emergency.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following words have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Air pollution.
para.text: "Air pollution" has the meaning stated in § 8-101(b) of this title

para.heading: Contractor.
para.text: "Contractor" means a person, firm, or legal entity with which the City has entered into an agreement.

para.heading: Debris.
para.text: "Contractor" means a person, firm, or legal entity with which the City has entered into an agreement.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Debris" means any solid material or portion of a solid material intended for disposal.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Debris" includes:
manufactured objects;
plant materials;
animal materials; and
natural geologic materials.

para.heading: Enforcement officer.
para.text: "Enforcement officer" has the meaning stated in City Code Article 1 § 41-1(c) {"Definitions: Enforcement officer"}.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Gas-powered debris removal equipment" means any device powered by an internal combustion or rotary engine using gasoline, alcohol, or any other fuel that is used to blow, vacuum, displace, or gather debris.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Gas-powered debris removal equipment" includes handheld leaf blowers with a vacuum function.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Gas-powered debris removal equipment" does not include:
lawn mowers;
lawn trimmers;
snow blowers;
pressure washers; or
self-propelled motorized leaf vacuums, including walk-behind, riding, and hitch mount leaf vacuums; and
leaf vacuum trucks.

para.heading: Landscape maintenance company.
para.text: "Landscape maintenance company" means a person who receives compensation, including money or material goods, in exchange for services that include:
lawns;
gardens;
trees;
plants; and
hardscape features; or
otherwise enhancing the aesthetics and functionality of an outdoor space.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Person" has the meaning stated in § 1-107(a) {"Person: In general"} of the City Code's General Provisions Article.

para.heading: Inclusion of governmental entities.
para.text: Notwithstanding § 1-107(b) {"Person: Exclusion"} of the General Provisions Article, in this subtitle "person" also includes a governmental entity or an instrumentality or unit of a governmental entity.

para.heading: Subcontractor.
para.text: "Subcontractor" means a business enterprise that has a direct contract with a contractor to perform part of the work on a contract.

section.heading: Prohibition of gas-powered debris removal equipment.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A person, individual, contractor, or subcontractor may not use gas-powered debris removal equipment in Baltimore City.

para.heading: Use on property.
para.text: An owner of real property in Baltimore City may not permit any person, individual, contractor, or subcontractor to use gas-powered debris removal equipment on that property.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act B Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Baltimore City Health Department or another City entity tasked with enforcement of this subtitle, shall adopt rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this subtitle and § 8-402 of this title.

para.heading: Required content.
para.text: The rules and regulations adopted by the Baltimore City Health Department under this section shall include an affidavit form a witness shall use to submit a complaint under § 8-402 of this title.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this title may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this title does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as otherwise specified in this subtitle, an enforcement officer may issue a civil or an environmental citation for violating the provisions of § 8-302 {"Prohibition of gas-powered debris removal equipment"} of this title if the enforcement officer:
witnesses the violation; or

receives from at least 1 witness a written complaint accompanied by photographic evidence and a signed affidavit in the form required by the rules and regulations promulgated pursuant to § 8-303 of this title {"Rules and regulations"}

para.heading: In general.
para.text: An enforcement officer who finds that any person person, individual, contractor, or subcontractor violated the provisions of § 8-302 {"Prohibition of gas-powered debris removal equipment"} of this title shall order, on a first offense, that the person, individual, contractor, or subcontractor cease and desist the use of gas-powered debris removal equipment.

para.heading: Requirements.
para.text: A special enforcement officer may find that a person, individual, contractor, or subcontractor has violated the provisions of § 8-302 {"Prohibition of gas-powered debris removal equipment"} of this title if the special enforcement officer:
witnesses the violation; or

receives from at least 1 witness a written complaint accompanied by photographic evidence and a signed affidavit in the form required by the rules and regulations promulgated pursuant to § 8-303 of this title{"Rules and regulations"}.
A person, individual, contractor, or subcontractor who commits a subsequent offense is subject to a fine of $250 for each subsequent offense.
Each day that a violation continues is a separate offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this title, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Impulse sound.
para.text: "Impulse sound" means a short burst of acoustical energy such as that produced by weapons fire, a punch press, or a drop hammer. A pressure time history of a single impulse includes a rapid rise to a maximum peak pressure followed by a somewhat slower decay, both occurring within 1 second.

para.heading: Motor vehicle.
para.text: "Motor vehicle" has the meaning stated in § 11-135 of the State Transportation Article {"Maryland Vehicle Law"}.

para.heading: Noise.
para.text: "Noise" means any steady-state or impulse sound that occurs on either a continuous or intermittent basis.

para.heading: Peak pressure.
para.text: "Peak pressure" is the sound level in decibels of an impulse sound measured with sound instrumentation that uses the flat response or linear scale.

para.heading: Steady-state sound.
para.text: "Steady-state sound" means a periodic or random variation, with a duration of more than 1 second, in atmospheric pressure at audible frequencies.

para.heading: Liberal construction.
para.text: This title is to be liberally construed to effectuate its purposes.

para.heading: Conflict with federal or state law.
para.text: This title is not to be construed to permit anything that is prohibited by any other federal, state, or local law or regulation.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: This title does not apply to any of the following:
motor vehicles, aircraft, or other equipment used in an emergency by any government agency or by any public service company, as defined in State Code Article 78; or
warning devices necessary for public safety, such as train horns and police, fire, and ambulance sirens.

para.heading: Qualified exemptions.
para.text: This title does not apply to the following, except as specifically stated in this title or where standards are set by the rules or regulations adopted by the Commissioner under § 2-106 {"Rules and regulations"} of this article :
motor vehicles; or
the construction, repair, or demolition of a structure or street.

annotations.annotation: Text conformed to include express cross-reference to § 2-106. Cf. Editor’s Note to that section.

para.heading: Commissioner may adopt.
para.text: The rules and regulations that the Commissioner adopts under § 2-106 {"Rules and regulations"} of this article may include provisions that set:
standards and procedures for measuring noise;
noise standards for motor vehicle operation;
noise standards for the construction, repair, or demolition of structures or streets;

standards, limitations, and procedures for obtaining a temporary exemption authorized by Subtitle 2 {"Basic Sound Level Standards"} or Subtitle 3 {"Entertainment and Commercial Noise"} of this title; and
other noise standards that the Commissioner considers necessary and appropriate for the protection of the public.

Before adopting any rules or regulations under this section, the Commissioner must hold a public hearing at which all interested persons are given an opportunity to testify on any proposed standard and to submit alternative proposals for the Commissioner's consideration.
Notice of the hearing must be published in a newspaper of general circulation in Baltimore City, at least once a week for the 2 successive weeks immediately before the hearing.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

"Decibel" or "dB" means the unit of measurement of relative sound intensity equal to 20 times the logarithm to the base 10 of the ratio of the effective sound pressure to a reference pressure of 20 micronewtons per square meter.
In formula,
dB = 20 Log10 P/P0
where P is the average pressure of the measured sound, and P0 indicates the reference pressure considered to be the weakest audible pressure a young ear can detect under ideal listening conditions.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Person" has the meaning stated in § 1-107(a) {"Person: In general"} of the City Code's General Provisions Article.

para.heading: Qualified inclusion of governmental entities.
para.text: Notwithstanding § 1-107(b) {"Person: Exclusion"} of the General Provisions Article, in this subtitle "person" also includes, except as used in § 9-218 {"Penalties"} of this subtitle, a governmental entity or an instrumentality or unit of a governmental entity.

para.heading: Sound Level A or db(A).
para.text: "Sound level A" or "dB(A)" is the sound level in decibels, measured with a sound level meter that uses the A-weighting network or scale, as specified in ANSI S1.4 ("Specification for Sound Level Meters"), as amended from time to time.

para.heading: Use.
para.text: "Use" means any activity, occupation, business, or operation that is conducted on land or in or on a street, building, pier, wharf, or other structure.

para.heading: Zone, commercial.
para.text: "Zone, commercial" means any of the following zoning districts established under the Baltimore City Zoning Code:
all Commercial Zoning Districts;
all OIC Office-Industrial Campus Zoning Districts;
all BSC Bio-Science Campus Zoning Districts;
all IMU-1 and IMU-2 Industrial Mixed-Use Zoning Districts; and
all TOD Transit-Oriented Development Zoning Districts.

para.heading: Zone, manufacturing.
para.text: "Zone, manufacturing" means any of the following zoning districts established under the Baltimore City Zoning Code:
all I-1 Light Industrial Zoning Districts;
all I-2 General Industrial Zoning Districts; and
all MI Maritime Industrial Zoning Districts.

para.heading: Zone, residential.
para.text: "Zone, residential" means any of the following zoning districts established under the Baltimore City Zoning Code:
all Residential Zoning Districts; and
all Office-Residential Zoning Districts.

para.heading: Findings.
para.text: The Mayor and City Council finds that excessive or unnecessary noise in the City is a menace to the welfare and prosperity of the people of the City.

para.heading: Policy.
para.text: It is the public policy of the City that:
everyone is entitled to an ambient noise level that is not detrimental to life, health, or enjoyment of property;
the ambient noise level in the City should be controlled and reduced:
to promote the public health, safety, and welfare and the peace and quiet of the City's inhabitants; and
to facilitate the enjoyment of the City's natural attractions; and
to those ends, standards for noise must be set and enforced, as provided in this subtitle.
No person may cause or permit a sound level that exceeds the applicable level specified in this subtitle.

No person may cause or permit a sound level from the construction, repair, or demolition of a structure or street that exceeds any applicable level set by a rule or regulation of Commissioner, except in accordance with a temporary exemption permit or as necessary to do emergency work.
No person may operate a motor vehicle so as to exceed any applicable sound level set by a rule or regulation of the Commissioner.
No person may use a vehicle horn except:
as reasonably necessary to assure safe operation; or
as an emergency warning signal.

para.heading: Measurements.
para.text: For sound levels set in this subtitle, measurements must be made with instruments calibrated by means of accepted acoustical techniques to an accuracy of plus or minus 1 dB(A).
Except as otherwise specified in this subtitle, the maximum permissible sound levels are as set in this section for the applicable zone.
Where the property line of a use coincides with a zone boundary, the level specified in this section for the zone boundary controls.
Where the use is on a public street, the "property line" referred to in this section is the boundary of the public right-of-way.

para.heading: Manufacturing zones.
para.text: If the sound is from a use in a manufacturing zone, the maximum permissible sound level is:
75 dB(A) at any point on the property line of the use;
70 dB(A) at any point on a boundary that separates the manufacturing zone from a commercial zone; and
70 dB(A) at any point on a boundary that separates the manufacturing zone from a residential zone.

para.heading: Commercial zones.
para.text: If the sound is from a use in a commercial zone, the maximum permissible sound level is:
61 dB(A) at any point on the property line of the use;
64 dB(A) at any point on a boundary that separates the commercial zone from a manufacturing zone; and
58 dB(A) at any point on a boundary that separates the commercial zone from a residential zone.

para.heading: Residential zone.
para.text: If the sound is from a use in a residential zone, the maximum permissible sound level is:
55 dB(A) at any point on the property line of the use;
61 dB(A) at any point on a boundary that separates the residential zone from a manufacturing zone; and
58 dB(A) at any point on a boundary that separates the residential zone from a commercial zone.

section.heading: Nighttime sound reductions.
section.text: Between the hours of 9 p.m. and 7 a.m., the maximum permissible sound specified in § 9-206 {"Limits"} of this subtitle must be reduced by 5 dB(A) for any use that:

para.text: borders on a residential zone; or
except for the level permitted by § 9-206(d)(2) of this subtitle, is in a residential zone.

para.heading: Short, durational deviations.
para.text: The maximum permissible sound levels specified in § 9-206 {"Limits"} of this subtitle may be exceeded by no more than:
5 dB(A) for a total of not more than 12 minutes in any 1-hour period;
10 dB(A) for a total of not more than 3 minutes in any 1-hour period; or
15 dB(A) for a total of not more than 30 seconds in any 1-hour period.

para.heading: Home activities — vehicle repairs; power tools.
para.text: Noncommercial vehicular repairs and the use of home workshops, power tools, and power garden equipment are allowed:
between the hours of 7 a.m. and 9 p.m. on weekdays; and
between the hours of 10 a.m. and 10 p.m. on weekends and legal holidays.

para.heading: Home activities — air conditioners; heat pumps.
para.text: Air conditioning and heat pump equipment used to cool or heat housing on residential property may exceed the maximum sound levels specified in § 9-206 {"Limits"} of this subtitle as long as the sound level does not exceed:
for air conditioning equipment, 70 dB(A) at any point on the property line of any other residential property; and
for heat pump equipment, 75 dB(A) at any point on the property line of any other residential property.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: When in the public interest, the Commissioner of Health may grant a temporary exemption from the maximum permissible sound levels specified in this subtitle.
An application for a temporary exemption must be made in the form that the Commissioner requires.
In addition to any other information that the Commissioner requires, the application must contain:
the name of the applicant;
the location of the property for which the exemption is requested;
the dates and hours for which the exemption is requested;
the equipment, instruments, or devices that will be producing the sound;
the name of the person in charge of operating the equipment, instruments, or devices; and
a statement of the reason the exemption is needed or appropriate.

para.heading: Form and contents of exemption.
para.text: A temporary exemption must:
be in writing;
be signed by the Commissioner; and
set forth:
the name of the person granted the exemption;
the location of the property for which the exemption is granted;
the dates and hours for which the exemption is effective;
the equipment, instruments, or devices to which the exemption is limited; and
any conditions or requirements that the Commissioner specifies.

para.heading: Exemption limitations.
para.text: A temporary exemption:
may be granted only for a period that is reasonable in view of all the facts, but in no case for more than 30 days;
may not be granted more than 3 times in any 1 calendar year for the same location; and
may not permit its holder to exceed the maximum permissible sound levels specified in this subtitle by more than 25 dB(A).

para.heading: In general.
para.text: If the Commissioner of Health believes that any provision of this subtitle has been violated, the Commissioner may issue a written notice to the alleged violator.

para.heading: Contents of notice and order.
para.text: The notice must:
specify the nature and facts of the violation, including the dB(A) readings noted and the time and place of their detection; and
order corrective action to be taken within the time the Commissioner specifies.

section.heading: Enforcement by Commissioner.
section.text: If corrective action is not taken within the time specified in the notice, the Commissioner may institute injunctive or other legal proceedings in a court of competent jurisdiction

para.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, any person may bring a civil action against any person who is in violation of a noise control requirement of this subtitle.
An action under this subsection may not be brought:
before 60 days after the complainant has given notice of the violation to the Commissioner and to the alleged violator; or
while the Commissioner is diligently prosecuting a civil action to require the alleged violator to comply with this subtitle.

para.heading: Action for civil damages.
para.text: Nothing in this subtitle limits the right of any person to damages or other relief for injury to person or property.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who neglects, refuses, or otherwise fails to comply with a notice issued under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 for each offense.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day a violation continues is a separate offense.

para.heading: Findings.
para.text: Having received an increasing number of complaints from citizens about noise and having made certain observations of the subject, the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore finds that:

excessive noise, when unnecessary for religious, political, civic, commercial, or other constitutionally protected activities or when not generated in the course of other activity needed to carry on daily life, creates a significant threat to the public health, safety, and welfare in an area as densely populated as Baltimore City;

the noises most obnoxious to the public health, safety, and welfare and least necessary for any constitutionally protected or otherwise necessary activity are those that are loud, boisterous, raucous, or unseemly or that are generated solely for the purpose of entertainment, without regard to the health, welfare, and safety of others who, because of population density, are unable to avoid being subjected to those noises; and

an alarming increase is occurring in the frequency and volume of this sort of noise, particularly from loud parties and from the plethora of portable sound-producing and reproducing devices available today.

para.heading: Intent.
para.text: The Mayor and City Council intend this subtitle, therefore, to serve as a vehicle for the control and regulation of noises that pose a threat to the health, safety, or welfare of the citizens of Baltimore. One part of this subtitle regulates noises generated solely for entertainment purposes. Another balances the public interest in regulating certain types of noisy commercial advertising to protect the public health, safety, and welfare, on the one hand, against the interests of the commercial establishments employing that advertising, on the other.

para.heading: Commercial, etc., speech.
para.text: This subtitle applies to commercial, religious, political, civic, or free speech activities only:
where the application is clearly indicated; or
where religious, fraternal, civic, political, charitable, or civic organizations provide entertainment, as in the case of "fund raisers" or similar activities.

para.heading: Exemptions from subtitle.
para.text: This subtitle does not apply to:
City-sponsored events in public parks;
sound equipment used at any professional sports stadium; or
any public service company, as defined in State Code Article 78.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Commissioner of Health may issue a permit for a temporary exemption from this subtitle for commercial, political, civic, charitable, or other organizations to conduct activities such as fund raisers, carnivals, bazaars, meetings, and other special events.
An application for a temporary exemption must be made in the form that the Commissioner requires.
In addition to any other information that the Commissioner requires, the application for must contain:
the name of the applicant;
the location of the property for which the exemption is requested;
the dates and the hours for which the exemption is requested;
the equipment, instruments, or devices that will be producing the sound;
the name of the person in charge of operating the equipment, instruments, or devices; and
a statement of the reason the exemption is needed or appropriate.

para.heading: Considerations.
para.text: Before issuing a temporary exemption, the Commissioner must consider the impact of the proposed activity on the surrounding area.

para.heading: Form and contents of exemption.
para.text: A temporary exemption must:
be in writing;
be signed by the Commissioner; and
set forth:
the name of the person granted the exemption;
the location of the property for which the exemption is granted;
the dates and hours for which the exemption is effective;
the equipment, instruments, or devices to which the exemption is limited; and
any conditions or requirements that the Commissioner specifies.

section.heading: Prohibited conduct — in general.
section.text: Except as authorized under § 9-303 {"Temporary exemptions"} of this subtitle, no person may play, operate, or permit to be played or operated any radio, musical instrument, phonograph, tape- or compact disc-player, or other device for the production or reproduction of sound if:

para.text: that sound is used or intended for entertainment; and
either:

the device is in a building or other structure or in a vehicle, and the sound can be heard more than 50 feet away from the building, structure, or vehicle or, if further, 50 feet from the boundaries of the property surrounding the building or structure;

the device is in or on a public street, building, park, or other public area, in or on a public access area, such as a shopping mall, parking lot, etc., or on any private property and the sound can be heard more than 50 feet from its source; or

the device is being played between 10 p.m. and 8 a.m. in or on a public street, unless the person is participating in a school band or a licensed parade or has otherwise been authorized to play the device.

section.heading: Prohibited conduct —parents or guardians of minors.
section.text: A parent or guardian may not knowingly permit a minor for whom the parent or guardian is responsible to violate § 9-306 {"Prohibited conduct — in general"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: Devices indoors.
para.text: If the device is located in a building or other structure or in a vehicle, the owner, occupant, resident, manager, operator, or other person in charge of the premises or vehicle, if present, is presumed to be responsible in the absence of evidence to the contrary.

para.heading: Devices outdoors.
para.text: If the device is outdoors, the person possessing it is presumed to be responsible in the absence of evidence to the contrary.

para.heading: Order to stop.
para.text: A police officer who finds any minor violating § 9-306 {"Prohibited conduct — in general"} of this subtitle must order the minor to stop the violation.
If the minor fails to comply with the order, the police officer may take him or her into custody.
After the information necessary to carry out the purposes of this subtitle has been recorded, the minor must be:
promptly released to his or her parent or guardian, with written notice to the parent or guardian of the violation; and
referred to the Baltimore City Police Department's court sanctioned pre-intake adjustment program.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: No commercial enterprise may broadcast over a loudspeaker or other device so that the sound can be heard more than 100 feet from the boundaries of the building or property where the device is located or, if the device is in a vehicle, more than 100 feet from that vehicle.

para.heading: Presumption.
para.text: The owner, manager, operator, or other person in charge of the building, premises, or vehicle from which the sound emanates is presumed to be responsible in the absence of evidence to the contrary.

para.heading: Restricted hours.
para.text: Except as specified in subsection (b) of this section, no person may sell anything by outcry between 10 p.m. and 8 a.m.

para.heading: Sporting events, etc.
para.text: This section does not apply to the sale of merchandise, food, or beverages at licensed sporting events, parades, fairs, circuses, and similar, licensed entertainment events.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle or of a rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, subject to the penalties specified in this section.

para.heading: Entertainment noise — adult offenders: $500 and 30 days.
para.text: For an adult who violates § 9-306 {"Prohibited conduct — in general"} of this subtitle, the penalty is a fine of not more $500 or imprisonment for not more than 30 days or both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: Entertainment noise — parent or guardian of minor: $100.
para.text: For a parent or guardian who violates § 9-307 {"Prohibited conduct —parents or guardians of minors"} of this subtitle within 12 months after receiving written notice of the minor's having violated § 9-306 {"Prohibited conduct — in general"} of this subtitle, the parent or guardian is subject to a fine of not more than $100 for each offense.

para.heading: Commercial noise — Outcrying: $1,000.
para.text: For any violation of § 9-313 {"Outcrying"} of this subtitle, the penalty is a fine of not more than $1,000 for each offense.

For any violation of § 9-312 {"Loudspeakers, etc."} of this subtitle, the penalty is a fine of not more than $1,000 or imprisonment for not more than 60 days or both fine and imprisonment for each offense.
Every day that a violation continues is a separate offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Commercial speech.
para.text: "Commercial speech" means speech or sound intended to promote any business or other activity carried on for profit.

para.heading: Market Center Urban Renewal Area.
para.text: "Market Center Urban Renewal Area" means the urban renewal area established by the Market Center Urban Renewal Plan.

para.heading: Publicly amplified sound.
para.text: "Publicly amplified sound" means any radio, phonograph, tape- or compact disc-player, loudspeaker, or other device that:
electronically produces, reproduces, or amplifies the human voice or other sound; and
is located:
on public property; or
on private property, but either:
in an unenclosed area; or
if in an enclosed area, within 9 feet of the nearest outside edge of the enclosed area.

The Mayor and City Council finds that the Market Center Urban Renewal Area serves the City in many important and irreplaceable ways. Most obviously, the area is a heavily used and essential retail and office district, providing job and shopping opportunities for countless thousands of City residents.

Equally important, however, is the traditional role that the area serves as a public forum for many diverse kinds of City residents. On any given day, dozens of people come to the district to promote their ideas on a wide variety of topics.

The Mayor and City Council further finds that publicly amplified sounds have hindered the use of the Market Center Urban Renewal Area, both as a shopping, office, and employment center and as a marketplace for the exchange of ideas.

While recognizing that, in some instances, the reasonable use of amplification equipment facilitates the exchange of ideas, the Mayor and City Council finds that the indiscriminate use of this equipment in the Market Center has created a condition demonstrably injurious to the health, welfare, and safety of the citizens of Baltimore.
Specifically, the Mayor and City Council finds that publicly amplified sound:
can be injurious to the health of those exposed to it;
when coming from or near a first floor business, impairs the use of offices above that business;
deters people from coming to the Market Center to shop, work, and exchange ideas;
hinders efforts to attract new businesses to the Market Center;
can be hazardous to pedestrians and motorists in the Market Center; and
aggravates an already-existing din that is caused by the architecture, building arrangement, proximity of businesses, and topography of the area and that is at its worst between 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.

para.heading: Intent.
para.text: Through the enactment of this subtitle, the Mayor and City Council intends:
to promote the use of the retail district both as a shopping, office, and employment center and as a marketplace for the exchange of ideas; and
to control the negative effects of publicly amplified sounds while allowing reasonable use of electronic amplification equipment.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: With respect to publicly amplified sounds in the Market Center Urban Renewal Area, this subtitle supersedes all other noise regulations of the City Code.

para.heading: Public service companies excepted.
para.text: This subtitle does not apply work performed by a public service company, as defined in State Code Article 78.

para.heading: Prohibited during certain hours.
para.text: In the Market Center Urban Renewal Area, between 11 a.m. and 3 p.m., Monday through Saturday, no person may use any publicly amplified sound that contains commercial speech.

para.heading: Permit required for other times.
para.text: At all other times in the Market Center Urban Renewal Area, no person may use any publicly amplified sound that contains commercial speech without a permit to do so from the Commissioner.

section.heading: Noncommercial speech.
section.text: At all times in the Market Center Urban Renewal Area, no person may use any publicly amplified sound not containing commercial speech without a permit to do so from the Commissioner.

section.heading: Loud and raucous sounds prohibited.
section.text: All loud and raucous sound is prohibited in the Market Center Urban Renewal Area. The receipt of a permit is not a defense to a charge of producing or causing any loud and raucous sound.

para.heading: Form.
para.text: An application for a permit must be made in the form that the Commissioner requires.

para.heading: Contents.
para.text: In addition to any other information that the Commissioner requires, the application must contain:
the name of the applicant;
the location of the property for which the permit is requested;
the dates and hours for which the exemption is requested;
the equipment that will be used to amplify sound; and
a statement as to whether the sound will contain commercial speech.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Commissioner must:
review each application for a permit within 3 days of its submission; and
on a reasonable showing that the amplifying equipment will not be used to produce loud and raucous sounds, promptly issue the permit to the applicant.

para.heading: Speech content not to be considered.
para.text: Except as needed to verify the noncommercial nature of any proposed speech, the Commissioner may not inquire into the content of the speech sought to be amplified.

para.heading: Fees.
para.text: The Commissioner may not charge a fee for the permit.

para.heading: Term.
para.text: Each permit:
is valid for 60 days; and
may be renewed an indefinite number of times.

para.heading: Commissioner to seek review.
para.text: Within 3 days after the Commissioner of Health denies any application for a permit, the Commissioner must:
apply to the Circuit Court for Baltimore City for a review of the denial; and
notify the applicant by first class mail of this action.

para.heading: Absence of Court decision.
para.text: If the Court does not render a decision within 10 days of the permit denial, the applicant may proceed as if a permit had been granted, subject to:
the same restrictions and obligations that apply to permits issued under this subtitle; and
immediate termination of all electronic amplification if the Court later affirms the Commissioner's denial.

para.heading: Appeal of decision.
para.text: If the Court affirms the Commissioner's denial of the permit, the Commissioner must cooperate with any motion for expedited appeal made by the applicant.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

section.heading: Penalties: $500 and 10 days.
section.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $500 or to imprisonment for not more than 10 days or to both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this title, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Alter.
para.text: "Alter" means to surgically or chemically render an animal incapable of reproducing.

para.heading: Animal.
para.text: "Animal" means any living creature other than a human being.

para.heading: Animal at large.
para.text: "Animal at large" has the meaning stated in § 10-504 of this title.

para.heading: Animal clinic.
para.text: "Animal clinic" means any facility that is regularly used by a veterinarian for the immunization, diagnosis, or treatment of or surgery on animals.

para.heading: Animal enforcement officer.
para.text: "Animal enforcement officer" has the meaning stated in § 10-110 {"Animal enforcement officers"} of this title.

para.heading: Animal fancier.
para.text: "Animal fancier" means a person who owns or keeps, within or adjoining a private residence, 2 or more animals for the non-commercial purposes of:
breeding;
hunting;
tracking;
exhibition in shows; or
exhibition in field or obedience trials.

para.heading: Animal shelter.
para.text: "Animal shelter" means any facility that is owned or operated by or under contract with the City or a humane society for the care or detention of animals under authority of State or City law.

para.heading: Animal show.
para.text: "Animal show" means any commercial circus, variety show, spectacle, display, act, or event in which animals perform.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Cat" means any domesticated feline.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Cat" does not include any:
wild or exotic feline; or
except as specifically stated, feral cat.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Commercial establishment" means, except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, any person engaged in the business of selling, transferring, or conveying animals or providing animal services.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Commercial establishments" includes any:
animal auction;
animal show;
commercial kennel;
commercial pet distribution or other facility where animals are held for sale at wholesale or for distribution to other commercial establishments or to zoological parks, aviaries, or aquariums;
grooming establishment or similar facility where animals are cleaned, bathed, clipped, plucked, or otherwise groomed for a fee;
stable or other facility for horses;
pet shop;
petting zoo or other commercial establishment, activity, or facility that permits persons to come into physical contact with animals maintained by the establishment, activity, or facility; or
zoological park.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Commercial establishments" does not include any:
animal clinic, unless it engages in the boarding of healthy animals not currently being treated by the clinic;
animal shelter; or
animal fancier.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Commercial kennel" means, except as specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection, any facility:
for the commercial breeding of dogs or cats; or
where dogs or cats are boarded, groomed, sold, bought, or trained for a fee.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Commercial kennel" does not include any:
animal clinic, unless it engages in the boarding of healthy animals not currently being treated by the clinic;
animal shelter; or
animal fancier.

para.heading: Custodian.
para.text: "Custodian" means a person:
who temporarily or permanently provides food, shelter, and care for an animal in the absence of the owner; or
who exercises control over the particular animal on a regular basis.

para.heading: Dangerous animal.
para.text: "Dangerous animal" has the meaning stated in § 10-702 of this title.

para.heading: Dog.
para.text: "Dog" means any member of the domesticated canine species.

para.heading: Domesticated animal.
para.text: "Domesticated animal" means any animal of a species that:
has been bred and raised and is accustomed to live in or about the habitation of humans; and
is dependent on humans for food or shelter.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Exotic animal" means:
any wild animal of a species that is not indigenous to the State of Maryland; and
any other animal that the Commissioner specifies by rule or regulation adopted under § 2-106 "Rules and regulations"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Exotic animal" includes any hybrid animal that is part exotic animal.

para.heading: Feral cat.
para.text: "Feral cat" means a cat that is unsocialized to humans and has a temperament of extreme fear of and resistance to contact with humans.

para.heading: Feral cat caregiver.
