container.heading: Costs of Care Pending Final Decision

section.heading: Office to hold animal.
section.text: If an impounded animal's owner or custodian requests a hearing before the Panel, or appeals a decision of the Panel, the Office may continue to hold and care for the impounded animal while its case is before the Panel, and, if the Panel's decision is appealed, while the Commissioner is considering the appeal.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: If an animal is held under § 10-1009 {"Office to hold animal"} of this subtitle while a requested hearing or appeal is pending, all costs for care or other expenses of the animal incurred by the Office from the time of impoundment through the Commissioner's final decision are a personal debt due to the City or its agent by the owner or custodian of the animal.

para.heading: Office to calculate.
para.text: The Office or its agent must, within a reasonable time of the final decision, calculate the cost, which may include:
food, veterinary care, and other necessities that a responsible owner or custodian would provide for the animal; and
other costs, such as staffing and administrative expenses, as allowed by rule or regulation adopted by the Commissioner under § 2-106 {"Rules and Regulations"} of this article.
The owner or custodian must pay the costs calculated by the Office within 72 hours of receiving notice from the Office or its agent of the amount.
The payment must be made in cash or other method acceptable to the Director of Finance.

para.heading: Administrative reversal.
para.text: If the final decision of the Commissioner overturns the impoundment, the City may not charge the owner or custodian for any costs incurred under this section.

annotations.annotation: Text of subsection (b) conformed to include express cross-reference to § 2-106. Cf. Editor’s Note to that section.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this title may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this title does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

Any person who violates any provision of this title, or a rule or regulation adopted under this title, or a lawful directive or order issued under this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to the penalties specified in this section.
Each day that a violation continues is a separate offense.

para.heading: Basic penalty: $1,000.
para.text: Except as otherwise specified in the section, the penalty for a violation is a fine of not more than $1,000 for each offense.

para.heading: Misrepresentation: $1,000 and 30 days.
para.text: For a violation of § 10-112 {"Obstructing, etc., officer; False statements"} of this title, the penalty is a fine of not more than $1,000 or imprisonment for not more than 30 days or both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: Animal Protection: $1,000 and 90 days.
para.text: For a violation of Subtitle 4 {"Animal Protection"} or Subtitle 9 {"Horse Riding and Driving"} of this title, the penalty is a fine of not more than $1,000 or imprisonment for not more than 90 days or both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: Attack dogs and vicious dogs: $1,000 and 6 months.
para.text: For a violation of § 10-701 {"Attack dogs"} or § 10-706 {"Vicious animals – Keeping prohibited"}of this title, the penalty is a fine of not more than $1,000 or imprisonment for not more than 6 months or both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this title, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Swimming pool" means any pool, hot tub, spa, or other body of water that is used for swimming, diving, wading, therapeutic, or recreational bathing.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Swimming pool" includes any body of water described in paragraph (1) of this subsection, whether:
in-ground, above-ground, or on-ground; or
indoor or outdoor.

section.heading: Compliance with Swimming Pool and Spa Code.
section.text: In addition to the requirements of this title, all swimming pools must comply with the International Swimming Pool and Spa Code, as adopted and modified in Part XII of the City Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article.

section.heading: "Private outdoor pool" defined.
section.text: In this subtitle, "private outdoor pool" means any swimming pool that :

para.text: is not a public swimming pool subject to Subtitle 3 {"Public Swimming Pools"} of this title; and
is not totally contained within a building and surrounded on all sides by the building's walls.

section.heading: Purpose.
section.text: The purpose of this subtitle is to protect the inhabitants of the City, particularly children, from the hazards to life and safety inherent in unenclosed outdoor swimming pools.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: This subtitle applies to all private outdoor pools in the City, whenever built.

para.heading: Subtitle sets minimum requirements.
para.text: This subtitle establishes minimum enclosure requirements only. All more stringent enclosure standards and other regulations imposed by the Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article of Baltimore City must be complied with to the extent applicable.

section.heading: Fence or wall required.
section.text: Every outdoor swimming pool must be completely surrounded by a fence or wall that:

para.text: is at least 42 inches high; and
except for doors or gates:
has no openings, holes, or gaps larger than 4 inches in any dimension; or
for a picket fence, has a horizontal distance between pickets of no more than 4 inches.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as specified in subsection (b) of this section, every gate or door opening through the enclosure must be equipped with a self-closing, self-latching device that keeps the gate or door securely closed at all times when not in actual use.

para.heading: Exception.
para.text: This section does not apply to the door of any dwelling house that forms a part of the enclosure.

section.heading: Owner and occupant responsible for compliance.
section.text: Compliance with the requirements of this subtitle is the duty, jointly and severally, of both:

para.text: the owner of premises; and
the person who occupies the land on which the outdoor swimming pool is located.

para.heading: Individual cases.
para.text: In individual cases, the Department of Housing and Community Development may modify one or more of the requirements of this subtitle on a showing of good cause and satisfactory assurances that the degree of protection is not reduced.

para.heading: Alternative devices.
para.text: The Department of Housing and Community Development also may permit the use of protective devices or structures other than those specified in this subtitle, so long as the degree of protection is not reduced.

section.heading: Penalties: $500.
section.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $500 for each offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Person" has the meaning stated in § 1-107(a) {"Person: In general"} of the City Code's General Provisions Article.

para.heading: Qualified inclusion of governmental entities.
para.text: Notwithstanding § 1-107(b) {"Person: Exclusion"} of the General Provisions Article, in this subtitle "person" also includes, except as used in § 11-318 {"Penalties"} of this subtitle, a governmental entity or an instrumentality or unit of a governmental entity.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Public swimming pool" means:
any swimming pool, other than as specified in paragraph (3) of this subsection, intended to be used collectively by individuals, regardless of whether a fee is charged for that use; and
all buildings and appurtenances used in connection with that swimming pool.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Public swimming pool" includes:
any community or apartment-complex swimming pool;
any hotel or motel swimming pool;
any school swimming pool;
any recreational center swimming pool; and
any swimming pool owned or operated by a public or private club.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Public swimming pool" does not include any swimming pool that is:
located on private property;
under the control of the owner or lessee of that property; and
used only by the family and guests of that owner or lessee, without payment of any fee.

section.heading: Scope of subtitle.
section.text: This subtitle applies to all public swimming pools and to the buildings and appurtenances used in connection with them.

para.heading: Standards and criteria.
para.text: The rules and regulations that the Commissioner adopts under § 2-106 {"Rules and regulations"} of this article may include criteria, standards, and regulations for the design, operation, and maintenance of public swimming pools.

para.heading: Fees.
para.text: With the approval of the Board of Estimates, the Commissioner may establish fees for:
the licenses issued under this subtitle; and
the inspections and other services performed by the Commissioner in connection with the regulation of public swimming pools.

para.heading: Inspections.
para.text: The Commissioner may inspect a public swimming pool as necessary or appropriate to assure compliance with the requirements of this subtitle and the rules and regulations adopted under it.

section.heading: In general.
section.text: No person may operate any public swimming pool in the City without a license to do so from the Commissioner of Health.

section.heading: Applications.
section.text: The application for a license must:

para.text: be in the form that the Commissioner requires; and
contain the information that the Commissioner requires.

section.heading: Issuance of license.
section.text: The Commissioner must issue a license to the applicant if:

para.text: the public swimming pool complies with the criteria, standards, and regulations adopted by the Commissioner; and
the applicant:
has complied with all other applicable laws, rules, and regulations; and
pays the applicable license and inspection fee.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Public swimming pool licenses are issued on an annual or seasonal basis.

para.heading: Annual licenses.
para.text: Unless sooner suspended or revoked, an annual license expires on the 1st anniversary of its effective date.
Unless sooner suspended or revoked, a seasonal license is valid from May 1 to October 1.
The application for a seasonal license must be submitted by April 1 of each year.

section.heading: License not transferable.
section.text: A license may not be transferred from place to place or person to person.

section.heading: In general.
section.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of Title 2, Subtitle 3 {"Administrative Hearings"} of this article, the Commissioner of Health may suspend or revoke any license issued under this subtitle if the licensee:

para.text: has withheld or falsified any information; or
neglects, refuses, or otherwise fails to comply with any provision of:
this subtitle; or
a rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle.

para.heading: Order of suspension.
para.text: If the Commissioner discovers a violation that represents a health or safety hazard to users of a pool, the Commissioner may issue an order of immediate suspension to the licensee.

para.heading: Contents.
para.text: An order issued under this section must:
cite the violation;
specify the corrective action to be taken; and
order all swimming operations to be discontinued immediately.

para.heading: Opportunity for hearing.
para.text: The notice must also state that a hearing will be provided to the licensee under Title 2, Subtitle 3 {"Administrative Hearings"} of this article, if one is requested.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of an environmental citation as authorized by City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of an environmental citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle or of a rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or to imprisonment for not more than 6 months or to both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day that a violation continues is a separate offense.

The prohibitions become effective February 1, 2008 {He § 24-504}. The State law expressly states that it does not “preempt a county ... from enacting and enforcing more stringent measures” {He § 24-510}.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Electronic smoking device" means an electronic or battery-operated device that delivers vapors for inhalation, whether manufactured , distributed, marketed, or sold:
as an electronic cigarette, electronic cigar, or electronic pipe; or
by any other product name or descriptor.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Electronic smoking device" does not include an asthma inhaler or similar product that:
contains no tobacco nor any nicotine; and
has been specifically approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for use in mitigating, treating, or preventing disease.
"Enclosed area" means an area that is bounded on all sides by walls that extend, with or without doors, windows, vents, or like openings, from floor to ceiling.
"Enclosed area" includes the interior of a vehicle.

para.heading: Person in charge.
para.text: "Person in charge" means the person who owns, operates, or manages a place subject to this subtitle.

para.heading: Smoke.
para.text: "Smoke" means to:
inhale, burn, or carry any lighted cigarette, cigar, or pipe tobacco, or any other tobacco, weed, or plant product of any kind; or.
to inhale vapors from or otherwise allow vapors to be emitted from an electronic smoking device.

section.heading: Scope.
section.text: Nothing in this subtitle precludes an employer or other person in charge from prohibiting smoking in open or enclosed areas not covered by this subtitle.

section.heading: Where smoking prohibited.
section.text: Except as otherwise specified in this subtitle, smoking is prohibited in:

para.text: any enclosed area to or in which the public is invited or permitted; or
any enclosed area that is part of a place of employment.

section.heading: Exceptions – General.
section.text: This subtitle does not apply to the following:

para.text: any part of a private residence that is not open to the public for business purposes, except as required by COMAR 13A.14.01.
a private vehicle.
a sleeping room in a hotel or motel, as long as that hotel or motel maintains at least 75% of all its sleeping rooms as smoke-free.
smoking as an integral part of a theatrical performance held in a facility primarily used for theatrical performances.
smoking as an integral part of a religious ceremony.
smoking at an analytical or educational laboratory as an integral part of scientific research into the health effects of smoke.
smoking that is permitted in a hospital, nursing home, or other health care facility under State Health-General Article, § 24-205.

section.heading: Exceptions – Retail tobacco establishments; Hookah lounges.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: This subtitle does not apply to a retail tobacco establishment or a hookah lounge that qualifies under this section.

para.heading: Retail tobacco establishments.
para.text: A retail tobacco establishment qualifies under this section only if it:
derives at least 75% of its revenues, measured by average daily receipts, from the sale of non-cigarette tobacco products;
has a ventilation system that prevents smoke from infiltrating into any area where smoking is prohibited under this subtitle; and
prohibits the entry of minors at all times.

para.heading: "Hookah lounge" defined.
para.text: In this subsection, "hookah lounge" means an establishment that is primarily devoted to the on-premises use of 1 or more hookahs (also known as a hookah pipe, water pipe, shisha, or narghile) for smoking tobacco or other substances.

para.heading: Qualifications.
para.text: A hookah lounge qualifies under this section only if it:
meets the criteria listed in State law;
derives at least 75% of its revenues, measured by average daily receipts, from the sale or use of non-cigarette smoking products and accessories;
has a ventilation system that prevents smoke from infiltrating into any area where smoking is prohibited under this subtitle; and
prohibits the presence of minors at all times.

section.heading: Exceptions – Retail sellers of electronic smoking devices.
section.text: This subtitle does not apply to the use of electronic smoking devices in a business establishment in which:

para.text: the primary activity is the retail sale of electronic smoking devices, accessories, and related products;
the sale of other products is incidental; and
the entry of minors is prohibited at all times.

section.heading: Exceptions – Electronic smoking devices in certain restaurants and taverns.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Restaurant.
para.text: "Restaurant" means a business establishment that:
is devoted primarily to serving food and drinks to the public for on-premises consumption by seated patrons; and
might or might not also serve alcoholic beverages.

para.heading: Tavern.
para.text: "Tavern" means a business establishment that:
is devoted primarily to serving alcoholic beverages to the public for on-premises consumption; and
might or might not also serve food.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: This subtitle does not apply to the use of electronic smoking devices in a restaurant or tavern or in 1 or more designated areas of a restaurant or tavern, as the case may be, if the establishment notifies its patrons and potential patrons that the use of electronic smoking devices is allowed on or in designated areas of the premises, as the case may be.
The notification required by this section must be provided both:
by a prominently posted notice, at least 17" x 22", that is clearly readable by all patrons on entry to the establishment; and
by a conspicuous notice, in at least 20-pt. font size, printed on each menu provided to patrons.
The tenor of the notices must be substantially as follows:
"This {restaurant / tavern} allows the use of electronic smoking devices {in designated areas / throughout the premises}."

section.heading: Exceptions – Electronic smoking devices in video lottery facility.
section.text: This subtitle does not apply to the use of electronic smoking devices in a facility that has been awarded a Video Lottery Operation License by the Maryland Video Lottery Location Commission under State Government Article, Title 9, Subtitle 1A.

para.heading: Authority to grant.
para.text: On written application, the Commissioner may grant a waiver from the application of a specific provision of this subtitle, if the applicant for the waiver establishes that:
compliance with that provision would cause undue financial hardship; or
other factors exist that would render compliance unreasonable.

para.heading: Conditions and restrictions.
para.text: The Commissioner may impose conditions or restrictions on the waiver as necessary or appropriate to:
minimize the adverse effects of the waiver on individuals involuntarily exposed to second-hand smoke; and
ensure that the waiver is consistent with the purposes of this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation as authorized by City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation as authorized by City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: Smoker: $500.
para.text: Any person who smokes in violation of this subtitle is subject to a civil fine of not more than $500 for each offense.
Any employer or other person in charge who violates a provision of this subtitle or who knowingly allows a violation is subject to a civil fine of not more than $750 for each offense.
It is an affirmative defense that the employer, other person in charge, or an agent of the employer or other person in charge:
posted a "No Smoking" sign at each entrance used by the public; and
removed all ashtrays and other smoking paraphernalia from all areas where smoking is prohibited; and
in a bar or restaurant:
refused to seat or serve any person who smoked where smoking is prohibited; and
if the person continued to smoke after an initial warning, asked the person to leave the establishment.
Each day that a violation continues is a separate offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Unpackaged cigarette.
para.text: "Unpackaged cigarette" means any cigarette not contained in a sealed package of 20 or more cigarettes that are designed and intended to be sold or distributed as a unit.

section.heading: Sale of unpackaged cigarettes prohibited.
section.text: No person may sell or otherwise transfer for consideration unpackaged cigarettes to any other person.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: Any person who violates any provisions of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 for each offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Distribute.
para.text: "Distribute" means to:
give, sell, deliver, or offer to give, sell, or deliver; or
cause or hire any person to give, sell, deliver, or offer to give, sell, or deliver.

para.heading: Less than basic cost.
para.text: "Less than basic cost" means:
free of charge;
for a nominal or discount price; or
for any other price that is less than the distributor's cost plus any applicable tobacco taxes.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Public place" means any area, whether open or enclosed, to which members of the public are normally invited or permitted.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Public place" includes parks, streets, sidewalks, sports fields, gymnasiums, shopping centers, and any property owned, occupied, or operated by the City.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Public place" does not include any retail store.

para.heading: Single cigarette.
para.text: This subtitle does not apply to the distribution of a single cigarette.

para.heading: Downtown area.
para.text: This subtitle does not apply anywhere in the area within and bounded by:
Centre Street on the north;
the Fallsway on the east;
Pratt Street on the south;

para.heading: Published coupons.
para.text: This subtitle does not apply to a coupon that is contained in a newspaper, magazine, or other type of publication in which the coupon is incidental to the primary purpose of the publication.

para.heading: Private functions.
para.text: This subtitle does not apply to the distribution of tobacco products or coupons at an event that is held in an enclosed area to which entry is not available to the general public but only to those whom the sponsor of the event invites.

para.heading: Tobacco company employees.
para.text: This subtitle does not apply to the distribution of tobacco products or coupons by a retailer, manufacturer, or distributor of tobacco products to its adult employees.

para.heading: Tobacco products.
para.text: Except as specified in § 12-302 {"Exemptions"} of this subtitle, no person in any public place or at any public event may distribute to a member of the public any tobacco product at less than basic cost.

para.heading: Coupons.
para.text: Except as specified in § 12-302 {"Exemptions"} of this subtitle, no person in any public place or at any public event may distribute to a member of the public any coupon that is redeemable for a tobacco product to members of the public in public places, in public areas or at public events.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $500 for each offense.

para.heading: Each distribution a separate offense.
para.text: Each person to whom a tobacco product is distributed constitutes a separate offense.

container.heading: Placement of Tobacco Products and Smoking Devices

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Electronic smoking device.
para.text: "Electronic smoking device" has the meaning stated in § 12-101 {"Definitions"} of this title.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Tobacco product" means any substance that contains tobacco.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Tobacco product" includes any:
cigarette;
cigar;
bidi;
pipe or other smoking tobacco; or
chewing tobacco, spit tobacco, snuff, or other smokeless tobacco.

para.heading: Prohibited placement.
para.text: Except as otherwise specified in this subtitle, no establishment that sells tobacco products or electronic smoking devices at retail may display, store, or place any tobacco product or electronic smoking device anywhere that is accessible to customers without the intervention of the seller or an employee of the seller.

para.heading: Examples of complying placement.
para.text: The display, storage, or placement of tobacco products or electronic smoking devices in accord with one of the following methods does not violate subsection (a) of this section:
behind a sales counter in a place that, absent extraordinary efforts, is beyond the physical reach of customers;
in a locked display case for which seller assistance is needed to gain access to products in the case; or
in an overhead merchandise rack that:
at its lowest point, is at least 6 feet above the floor; and
permits access to products in the rack only from the side facing away from customers.

section.heading: Placement requirements — Exceptions.
section.text: This subtitle does not apply to:

para.text: the sale of tobacco products or electronic smoking devices from a vending machine that complies with all requirements of State Business Regulation Article, Title 16, Subtitle 3A; or
an establishment that:
sells tobacco products or electronic smoking devices exclusively or primarily; and
makes bona fide efforts to prevent minors from entering the establishment.

an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or

para.heading: In general.

para.text: Each day that a violation continues is a separate offense.

cause or hire any person to:

Intended for human inhalation, absorption, ingestion, smoking, heating, chewing, dissolving, or any other manner of consumption that is made of, derived from, or contains:

para.heading: Persons in business.
para.text: A person engaged in the business of selling or otherwise distributing tobacco products for commercial purposes may not:

distribute any tobacco product to an individual under the age of 21 years, unless the individual is acting solely as the agent of an employer engaged in the business of distributing those products or devices;
distribute any cigarette rolling paper to an individual under the age of 21 years; or
distribute to an individual under the age of 21 years any coupon redeemable for any tobacco product.

para.heading: Others.
para.text: A person not described in subsection (a) of this section may not:
buy for or sell to an individual under the age of 21 years any tobacco product; or
buy for or sell or deliver to an individual under the age of 21 years any cigarette rolling paper.

para.heading: Published coupon.
para.text: This subtitle does not apply to the distribution of a coupon that is:
contained in a newspaper, magazine, or other type of publication in which the coupon is incidental to the primary purpose of the publication; or
sent through the mail.

para.heading: Identification of age.
para.text: A person has not violated this subtitle if:
the person examined a buyer's or recipient's driver's license or other identification issued by an employer, governmental entity, or institution of higher education; and
the license or other identification identified the buyer or recipient as being at least 21 years old.

para.heading: Active duty military.
para.text: A person has not violated this subtitle if:
the person examined a buyer's or recipient's valid military identification; and
the identification indicated that the buyer or recipient is:
an active duty member of the military; and
at least 18 years old.

para.text: "Flavored tobacco wrapping" means any cigarette rolling paper or tobacco wrapping leaf or paper constituted from tobacco that is, or is held out to be, impregnated or scented with, or aged or dipped in, or has as a constituent part (including a smoke constituent) or additive, an artificial or natural flavor, alcoholic liquor, or an herb or spice, including strawberry, grape, orange, clove, cinnamon, pineapple, coconut, licorice, cocoa, cherry, coffee, chocolate, vanilla, honey, or any other flavoring agent that is a characterizing flavor of the tobacco product or the tobacco smoke.

section.heading: Distribution prohibited
section.text: No person may distribute for consideration any flavored tobacco wrapping to any other person.

section.heading: Exception for certain tobacco shops.

para.text: derives at least 75% of its revenues, measured by average daily receipts, from the sale of non-cigarette tobacco products;

prohibits the entry of minors at all times.

para.text: "Athletic facility" means any outdoor facility clearly intended for playing sports.

para.text: "Athletic facility" includes any:
baseball diamond;
soccer, lacrosse, or football field;
basketball court;
racing track;
skating rink; or
field hockey pitch.

section.heading: Where smoking prohibited.
section.text: Except as otherwise specified in this subtitle, smoking is prohibited in or within 50 feet of any:

schoolyard;
athletic facility; or
public swimming pool.

para.heading: Tattoo.
para.text: "Tattoo" means to prick, pierce, or otherwise enter the skin or the mucous membrane of an individual for the purpose of inserting pigments or raising scars.

para.heading: Tattoo establishment.
para.text: "Tattoo establishment" means any place at which a tattoo is administered for any form of consideration.

para.heading: Tattooist.
para.text: "Tattooist" means any individual who administers a tattoo for any form of consideration.

section.heading: License required for tattoo establishments.
section.text: No person may maintain, operate, or conduct a tattoo establishment in the City without a license to do so from the Commissioner of Health.

section.heading: Registration required for tattooists.
section.text: No tattoo establishment may employ or otherwise allow any individual to act as a tattooist, and no individual may act as a tattooist, unless that individual has first registered with the Commissioner of Health.

section.heading: Applications for license.
section.text: An application for a tattoo establishment license must:

para.text: be on the form that the Commissioner provides; and
contain the information that the Commissioner requires.

section.heading: Issuance of license; fee.
section.text: The Commissioner must issue a license to the applicant on receipt of:

para.text: a completed application; and
the annual license fee of $100.

section.heading: Term.
section.text: Unless sooner revoked, a license issued under this title expires annually on the anniversary of its issuance.

section.heading: Safety and sanitary standards.
section.text: All tattooing must be done in conformance with:

para.text: the State regulations governing skin-penetrating body adornment procedures (COMAR 10.06.01.06H); and
any additional conditions that the Commissioner adopts to protect the public health.

section.heading: Tattooing minors prohibited.
section.text: No person may tattoo any minor.

section.heading: Suspensions, revocations, etc.
section.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of Title 2, Subtitle 3 {"Administrative Hearings"} of this article, the Commissioner may suspend, revoke, or refuse to renew the license or registration of any person if that person, that person's tattoo establishment, or any tattooist employed by that person violates any provision of this title or of any order, rule, or regulation issued under this title.

para.heading: Firearm.
para.text: "Firearm" means any pistol, revolver, rifle, shotgun, short-barreled rifle, short-barreled shotgun, or other firearm.

para.heading: Minor.
para.text: "Minor" means any person under the age of 18.

section.heading: Sale, etc., to minors prohibited.
section.text: No person may sell, give, or otherwise transfer, or attempt to sell, give, or otherwise transfer any ammunition to a minor.

section.heading: Purchase, etc., by minors prohibited.
section.text: No minor may:

para.text: purchase or attempt to purchase any ammunition; or
possess any ammunition in any public place.

section.heading: Photo ID required.
section.text: No person may sell, give, or otherwise transfer or attempt to sell, give, or otherwise transfer any ammunition to any individual without first verifying, by means of photographic identification that contains the individual's date of birth, that the individual is not a minor.

para.text: Except as specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection, every person engaged in the business of selling ammunition must apply to the Commissioner of Health for a "Protections of Minors" registration.
This section does not apply to a person who is licensed under State Code Article 27, § 443 as a regulated firearms dealer.

para.heading: Form and information.
para.text: The registration must:
be on the form that the Commissioner provides;
contain the information that the Commissioner requires; and
be supplemented within 30 days of any change in the information submitted.

para.heading: Fees.
para.text: Registration fees are as follows:
Initial registration of business – $10.
Supplementation of information – $5.

section.heading: Notices.
section.text: Every person engaged in the business of selling ammunition must post conspicuously in that person's place of business a notice of:

para.text: the prohibition in § 14-103 of this title against the transfer of ammunition to minors; and
the requirement in § 14-105 of this title for age verification.

para.heading: Required.
para.text: Every person engaged in the business of selling ammunition must keep a log of all ammunition sales.

para.heading: Contents.
para.text: The sales log must contain, for each sale of ammunition:
a copy of the sales receipt; and
a copy of the purchaser's photographic identification, clearly showing the purchaser's name and date of birth.

para.heading: Inspection.
para.text: During business hours, the sales log must be kept near the register and made available for inspection by any police officer or any designee of the Commissioner.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: In the rules and regulations adopted under § 2-106 {"Rules and regulations"} of this article, the Commissioner may include provisions governing:

para.text: registration information to be provided and, from time to time, supplemented under § 14-107 of this title;
the wording, size, and placement of the notices required by § 14-108 of this title; and
the form of and information to be recorded in the sales log required by § 14-109 of this title.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Psychoactive substance" means any:
synthetic cannabinoid;
synthetic cathinone; or
psychoactive substance analogue.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Psychoactive substance" does not include a substance that:
has an approved drug application by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration; and
is being distributed in accordance with all applicable federal and state laws and regulations.

para.heading: Psychoactive substance analogue.
para.text: "Psychoactive substance analogue" means a substance that:
is an alkyl homologue of a synthetic cannabinoid or synthetic cathinone; or
in its chemical structure, differs from a synthetic cannabinoid or synthetic cathinone only by:
substituting 1 or more hydrogens with halogens; or
substituting 1 or more halogens with different halogens.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Synthetic cannabinoid" means a chemically engineered substance that:
has binding activity at 1 or more cannabinoid receptors;
is a chemical analogue or isomer of a compound that has binding activity at 1 or more cannabinoid receptors; or
is identified as a cannabimimetic agent, as defined in State Code Criminal Law Article § 5-101.

para.heading: Illustrations.
para.text: A synthetic cannabinoid is commonly, but not exclusively, found sprayed on dried herbs, to be burned and inhaled by consumers.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Synthetic cathinone" means a chemically engineered derivative of cathinone, which is a naturally occurring beta-ketone amphetamine analogue found in the leaves of the catha edulis plant.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Synthetic cathinone" includes butylone, dimethylcathinone, ethcathinone, ethylone, 3- and 4-fluoromethcathinone, mephedrone, methedrine, methylenedioxypyrovalerone (MDVP), methylone, and pyrovalerone.

para.heading: Illustrations.
para.text: A synthetic cathinone is commonly, but not exclusively, found in the form of pills, capsules, crystals, powders, tablets, or liquids.

section.heading: Distribution prohibited.
section.text: No person may distribute a psychoactive substance.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Whenever the Commissioner reasonably believes that a person is distributing a psychoactive substance in violation of this title, the Commissioner shall issue a violation notice to the person.

para.heading: Contents.
para.text: The violation notice must:
cite the violation;
specify any corrective action to be taken and the time within which that action must be taken; and
state that a hearing will be provided to the person, if one is requested under Title 2, Subtitle 3 {"Administrative Hearings"} of this article.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: On reasonable belief that a violation of this title has occurred, the Commissioner may:
seize and detain any product suspected to be a psychoactive substance;
submit the seized product for laboratory testing and analysis;
retain for use in further proceedings any seized product found to be a psychoactive substance; and
destroy any product ultimately determined to be a psychoactive substance involved in a violation of this title.

para.heading: Return of non-psychoactive substances.
para.text: Any product found not to be a psychoactive substance involved in a violation of this subtitle must be promptly returned to the person from whom seized, less any amount destroyed for testing.

section.heading: "License" defined.
section.text: In this Part II, "license" means a license or permit issued by the Baltimore City Health Department.

section.heading: Suspension or revocation on notice and hearing.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Commissioner may suspend or revoke the license of a person if the licensee has first been issued a violation notice under § 16-301 {"Notice of Violation"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: Opportunity for hearing.
para.text: Before suspending or revoking a license, the Commissioner must provide the licensee with notice and opportunity for hearing, as provided In Title 2, Subtitle 3 {"Administrative Hearings"} of this article.

para.heading: Order of immediate suspension.
para.text: If the Commissioner considers it necessary and in the interest of public health and safety because of exigent circumstances where public health and safety are under imminent threat, the Commissioner may issue an order of immediate suspension to a licensee without having first issued a violation notice under § 16-301 {"Notice of Violation"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: Content.
para.text: An order issued under this section:
must cite the violation;
must specify the corrective action to be taken and the time within which that action must be taken; and
may order all of the licensee's operations to be discontinued immediately.

para.heading: Opportunity for hearing.
para.text: The notice must also state that a hearing will be provided to the licensee under Title 2, Subtitle 3 {"Administrative Hearings"} of this article, if one is requested.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this title may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

section.heading: Criminal penalties.
section.text: Any person who violates any provision of this title or of a rule or regulation adopted under this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or imprisonment for not more than 12 months or to both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

section.heading: Each package or container a separate offense.
section.text: Each package or container of a psychoactive substance that is distributed or intended for distribution in violation of this title is a separate offense.

para.heading: Grave depth.
para.text: Every grave dug in any cemetery or burial ground must be at least 4' 6" deep.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, subject to a fine of not more than $100 for each offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: "Approved protective gear".
para.text: "Approved protective gear" means protective eye, head, and body equipment that meets or exceeds standards set by any of the following for use in youth baseball:
the American National Standards Institute;
the American Society of Testing and Measurements;
the Snell Memorial Foundation; or
any other organization that the Health Commissioner designates for this purpose.

para.heading: "Youth baseball".
para.text: "Youth baseball" means any baseball game or practice session held under the auspices of:
Little League Baseball; or
any other organization of 2 or more teams.

para.heading: Protective gear required.
para.text: No individual under the age of 16 may participate in youth baseball, at any position, unless she or he is wearing approved protective gear of the type the Commissioner designates as appropriate for that position.

para.heading: Rules and regulations.
para.text: In the rules and regulations adopted under § 2-106 {"Rules and regulations"} of this article, the Health Commissioner must include provisions, consistent with this section, that designate:
the types of protective gear that are appropriate for each playing position; and
the organizations whose standards may be used for determining whether equipment is approved protective gear for purposes of this section.

para.heading: Enforcement.
para.text: This section is enforced by the issuance of a warning that:
informs the offender of the requirements of this section; and
contains educational materials about approved protective gear for youth baseball.

This campaign may include media buys and placements and public service announcements.”
Section 5 of the Ordinance further provides that, except as provided in Sections 3 and 4, Ordinance 20-430 takes effect on July 1, 2022.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this title, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Agriculture.
para.text: "Agriculture" means the commercial production, storage, processing, marketing, distribution, or export of an agronomic, aquacultural, equine, floricultural, horticultural, ornamental, silvicultural, or viticultural crop, including:
a farm product;
livestock or a livestock product;
poultry or a poultry product;
milk or a dairy product;
timber or a forest product;
fruit or a horticultural product; and
seafood or an aquacultural product.

para.heading: Custom applicator.
para.text: "Custom applicator" means a person engaged in the business of applying pesticides.

para.heading: Glyphosate.
para.text: "Glyphosate" means a synthetic compound that is a non-selective systemic herbicide, also known as N-(phosphonomethyl) glycine with a chemical formula of C3H8NO5P.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Lawn" means an area of land, not used for agriculture, that is:
mostly covered by grass, other similar herbaceous plants; and
kept trim by mowing or cutting.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Lawn" does not include:
a playing field as defined in § 19-301 of this title;
a golf course;
a garden; or
a tree or shrub.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Neonicotinoid" means a class of neuro-active pesticides chemically related to nicotine.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Neonicotinoid" includes:
acetamiprid;
clothianidin;
dinotefuran;
imidacloprid;
nitenpyram;
nithiazine;
thiacloprid; and
thiamethoxam.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Person" has the meaning stated in § 1-107(a) {"Person: In general"} of the City Code's General Provisions Article.

para.heading: Inclusion of governmental entities.
para.text: Notwithstanding § 1-107(b) {"Person: Exclusion"} of the General Provisions Article, in this subtitle "person" also includes a governmental entity or an instrumentality or unit of a governmental entity.

para.heading: Pest.
para.text: "Pest" means an insect, snail, slug, rodent, nematode, fungus, weed, or other form of plant or animal life or microorganism (except a microorganism on or in a living human or animal) that is normally considered to be a pest or defined as a pest by applicable State regulations.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Pesticide" means a substance or mixture of substances intended or used:
to prevent, destroy, repel, or mitigate any pest;
as a herbicide, plant regulator, defoliant, or desiccant; or
as a spray adjuvant, such as a wetting agent or adhesive.

para.heading: Exclusion.
para.text: "Pesticide" does not include an antimicrobial agent, such as a disinfectant, sanitizer, or deodorizer, that is used for cleaning and is not considered a pesticide under any federal or state law or regulation.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Playground" has the meaning stated in § 12-801(c) of this article {"Definitions: Playground"}.

para.heading: Inclusion.
para.text: "Playground" includes a mulched path that is used to enter a playground.

para.heading: Registered pesticide.
para.text: "Registered pesticide" means a pesticide registered by the United States Environmental Protection Agency and labeled pursuant to the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide and Rodenticide Act for use in lawn, garden, and ornamental sites or areas.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Mayor and City Council finds as follows:
Pesticides have value when they are used to protect the public health, the environment, and our food and water supply.
Pesticides, by definition, contain toxic substances, many of which may have a detrimental effect on human health, pet health, and the environment.
Certain pesticides have been linked to a host of serious conditions in children including pediatric cancers, decreased cognitive function, and behavioral problems.

Certain pesticides have been linked to a myriad of adult conditions such as Parkinson's disease, diabetes, lupus, rheumatoid arthritis, dementia, reproductive dysfunction, Alzheimer's disease, and a variety of cancers including leukemia, lymphoma, breast cancer, colorectal cancer, prostate cancer, and lung cancer.

Certain pesticides, especially those containing the chemical glyphosate, have been linked to cancer. For example, in 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer, a division of the World Health Organization and the world's leading authority on cancer, unanimously concluded that glyphosate is a probable carcinogen. The International Agency for Research on Cancer's determination was based on a rigorous assessment that concluded that there is sufficient evidence of carcinogenicity in experimental animals.

Clean water is essential to human life, wildlife and the environment, and the unnecessary use of pesticides contributes to the deterioration of water quality, as substantiated by several studies including a 2014 USGS study that found 90% of urban waterways have pesticide levels high enough to harm aquatic life.

Bees and other pollinators are crucial to our ecosystem, and the use of neonicotinoid insecticides, which have been repeatedly and strongly linked with the collapse of honey bee colonies, as well as harm to aquatic insects and birds, pose an unacceptable risk to beneficial organisms.

The use of pesticides is not necessary for the management of lawns, especially in light of the risks associated with their use. There are non- and less-toxic alternatives and methods of cultivating a healthy, green lawn that do not pose a threat to public health.

Regulations at the federal and State level, and the risk assessments that inform them, do not mimic real world exposure scenarios and fail to account for synergistic or cumulative effects of multiple chemicals acting on the same pathway; they do not include sufficient evaluation of a pesticide's "inert" ingredients and the pesticide formulations that are sold to consumers; and they often fail to take sensitive populations like children and pollinators into account.
In the absence of adequate regulation at the federal or State level, Baltimore City is compelled to act to protect the health of children, families, pets, and the environment.

The purpose of this title is to protect the public health and welfare and to minimize the potential pesticide hazard to people and the environment, consistent with the public interest in the benefits derived from the safe use and application of pesticides.

The goal is to inform the public about pesticide applications and minimize the use of pesticides, while not restricting the ability to use pesticides in agriculture, for the protection of public health, or for other public benefit.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: In the rules and regulations adopted under § 2-106 {"Rules and regulations"} of this article, the Commissioner must include rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this title.

annotations.annotation: Text conformed to include express cross-reference to § 2-106. Cf. Editor’s Note to that section.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: No later than June 30 of each odd-numbered year, the Department and the Baltimore City Office of Sustainability shall jointly submit a report to the Mayor and City Council that makes recommendations on whether any legislative changes or updates are necessary for the proper administration and implementation of this title.

para.heading: Specific pesticides.
para.text: The report required by this section shall include an assessment, relying on available scientific data, regarding:
whether any additional pesticides pose a significant threat to the health of the citizens of Baltimore or the environment; and
whether those pesticides should be included within this title's specific pesticide prohibitions.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Children's facility" means a building or part of a building that, as part of its function, is
regularly occupied by children under the age of 18 years; and
required to obtain an use and occupancy permit as a condition of performing that function.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Children's facility" includes a child day care center, family day care home, nursery school, recreational center, and classroom.

para.heading: Disease vector.
para.text: "Disease vector" means an animal, insect, or microorganism that carries and transmits an infectious pathogen into another organism.

para.heading: Listed pesticide.
para.text: "Listed pesticide" means:

a pesticide the active ingredients of which are recommended by the National Organic Standards Board (NOSB) pursuant to 7 U.S.C. § 6518, as amended, and published as the National List at 7 C.F.R. §§ 205.601 and 205.602; or
a pesticide designated a "minimum risk pesticide" under the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide and Rodenticide Act § 25(b) and listed in 40 C.F.R. § 152.25(f).

para.heading: Mulched recreation area.
para.text: "Mulched recreation area" means an area of land covered with natural or synthetic mulch or wood chips that is open to the public for picnic or recreational use.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Playing field" means:
an athletic field owned or maintained by a department or unit of Baltimore City government; or
an area of land on private property maintained exclusively for athletic or sporting use.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Playing field" does not include any artificial surface such as astro-turf or concrete.

section.heading: Scope of subtitle - Baltimore City Public School System properties.
section.text: Nothing in this subtitle applies to any property that is used and maintained by the Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, no person may apply any pesticide other than a listed pesticide to any:
lawn;
playground;
mulched recreation area;
children's facility;
grounds of a children's facility; or
playing field.

para.heading: Permitted applications.
para.text: Except as provided in § 19-303 {"Glyphosate use prohibited"}, § 19-304 {"Chlorpyrifos use prohibited"}, and § 19-305 {"Neonicotinoid pesticides on City-owned property"} of this title, a person may apply any registered pesticide to:
control weeds, as required by Title 5, Subtitle 7, of this article;
control invasive species, as defined and listed in regulations adopted under this title;
control disease vectors;
control biting or stinging insects or stinging plants;
control organisms that threaten the health of trees or shrubs;
maintain property as part of efforts by a public utility to comply with applicable vegetation management provisions of any federal, state, or local law or regulation;
control indoor pests, if applied near or around the foundation of a building;
comply with § 3318 {"Rodenticide Procedure"} of the City Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article;
control pests while engaged in agriculture; or
control a pest outbreak that poses an imminent threat to human health or threatens significant economic damage if a registered pesticide is not used.

para.heading: Emergency applications.
para.text: If a pesticide is applied under subsection (b)(10) of this section, the person applying the pesticide must notify the Department of the application and articulate the reasons for the use of the pesticide within 24 hours after the application.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of this title, a person may not use or apply glyphosate or any product containing glyphosate except when authorized under subsection (b) of this section.

The Commissioner may authorize the use or application of glyphosate on a determination that a threat exists that requires the use of glyphosate and no other pesticide or class of pesticide would be effective in addressing the threat.
The Department of Recreation and Parks may engage in the limited use and application of glyphosate subject to a written Integrated Vegetation Management Plan that details:
the locations of glyphosate use and application;
the necessity for glyphosate use and application in those locations; and
any preventive or mitigative measures undertaken to protect the health and safety of those within the vicinity of the glyphosate use and application.
Any Intregrated Vegetation Management Plan that includes the use and application of glyphosate shall be submitted to the Commissioner prior to any use and application.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of this title, a person may not use or apply chlorpyrifos or any product containing chlorpyrifos except when authorized by the Commissioner under subsection (b) of this section.

para.heading: Authorized use.
para.text: The Commissioner may authorize the use or application of chlorpyrifos on a determination that a threat exists that requires the use of chlorpyrifos and no other pesticide or class of pesticide would be effective in addressing the threat.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a City employee or City contractor may not use a neonicotinoid pesticide on outdoor property owned by the City.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: A City employee or City contractor may use a neonicotinoid pesticide on City-owned property to control pests:
while engaged in agriculture; or
in a completely indoor and enclosed area, such as a greenhouse or a conservatory.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day a violation continues is a separate offense.

para.heading: Written warning required.
para.text: A citation under this section may only be issued after the issuance of a written warning.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $250 for each offense.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day that a violation continues is a separate offense.
